We study energy transfer in a coupled nonlinear oscillator network with time delays, inspired by the dynamics of biological systems such as neural networks and gene regulatory networks.
We indicate that there exists an optimal coupling strength for each independent oscillator to achieve maximum energy transfer efficiency among all other oscillators.
The results were obtained through numerical simulations of small-scale and large-scale networks.
In particular, we found that when the number of nodes exceeds a certain threshold, the energy transfer efficiency decreases.
This phenomenon can be explained by the following fact: due to the increase in the number of nodes, the total energy available for each node decreases rapidly.
Finally, we discuss the possibility of applying our findings to real-world problems.
Energy transfer plays an important role in many natural phenomena, including brain activity [1] and heartbeat.

We present the results of an optical spectroscopy survey of radio galaxies in clusters at redshift z = 0.4-0.8, conducted using the William Herschel Telescope (WHT).
We found that in star clusters, the proportion of radio galaxies driven by active galactic nuclei decreases in environments with higher galaxy density.
This is consistent with previous research findings, which have shown evidence of environmental suppression of star formation activity in massive galaxies.
However, we also found many examples where powerful radio sources are located in dense regions without obvious signs of environmental suppression.

We presented observations of the asymmetry of the Mg II k line during flares and compared them with the results of numerical simulations conducted using the RH code (Uitenbroek 2001).
The observed profile shows that at all heights above the limbs from which we can see the flare emission, the blue wing has an enhancement relative to the red wing.
This effect is more pronounced at higher altitudes.
We found that this behavior cannot be explained solely by the Doppler shift caused by the movement of the volume plasma in the direction of the line of sight.
In addition, our model shows that if the non-thermal electron beam is not taken into account as an additional heating source, the observed profile shape cannot be reproduced.
Keywords: solar flares, chromospheric line, non-thermal electrons, radiative hydrodynamic model, RH code, Mg II k line, spectral line asymmetry.

1 Introduction

The intense energy release of solar flares leads to rapid changes in the physical conditions of the solar atmosphere.
These include temperatures that can rise to millions of Kelvin, strong magnetic fields, high density, and large velocities.
All these factors can affect the shape of the spectral lines emitted by different layers of the atmosphere.

For example, it has been shown that the intensity ratio between two Fe I lines formed at different temperatures depends on the formation height of each line (Feldman et al., 1995; Brosius & Phillips, 2004).

Additionally, the presence of non-thermal electrons leads to a significant deviation in the Maxwell velocity distribution, resulting in asymmetry in the spectral line profile (e.g., Canfield et al. 1990; Doschek et al. 1991). Overall flow also causes a Doppler shift in the center position of the spectral line (Doschek et al. 1991; Brosius and Phillips 2004; Brosius 2009).
Therefore, studying the temporal evolution of linear profiles provides important information about the dynamics of flaring regions.
However, interpreting these data requires a deep understanding of the fundamental physical principles involved in the processes that lead to the observed phenomena.
In particular, the study of the Mg II h & k lines provides a unique opportunity to investigate various aspects of solar flares, as they form over a wide range.
The purpose of this study is to examine how an organization uses the Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) as a process optimization tool within its service center environment.
This study focuses on the release management process at the Information Technology Service Center of Harz University and examines whether it aligns with all relevant aspects of the ITIL framework.
The data was collected using a case study method through interviews and document analysis.
This article presents the survey results on the current status of the release management process at the IT Service Center of Harz University.
It also provides recommendations for improving the process based on the findings.
Keywords: Information Technology Infrastructure Library, process optimization, release management process, university, IT service center, case study method.

The dielectric properties, phase transition behavior, and microstructural evolution of (0.65[Pb(Ni-1/3Nb-2/3)O_3] -0.35PbTiO3) (PNT) ceramics were studied at different sintering temperatures (850 to 1100 °C).

The PNT samples exhibited a high dielectric constant value, reaching about 10^4, with a loss tangent of less than 10^-2. At a field strength of 30 kV/cm at room temperature, they demonstrated a tunability of over 30%.
As the temperature decreases to 77 K, the dielectric constant slightly increases, while the loss tangent significantly decreases due to the freezing of mobile ions.
At low temperatures, two relaxation processes are observed in the frequency range from 1 Hz to 100 kHz.
The first process is attributed to the grain boundary effect; as the temperature decreases, it shifts to higher frequencies.
The second process is related to the movement of ferroelectric domain walls; when the temperature changes, its relaxation time constant remains almost unchanged.
Social networks are ubiquitous in our daily lives and have become a subject of extensive research for scholars across various disciplines.
However, due to the complexity of social network data, analyzing this data is often challenging.
In this work, we propose NodeTrix, an effective hybrid representation that can efficiently analyze large-scale social networks.
We demonstrated how NodeTrix can be applied to solve several important problems, including community detection, link prediction, node classification, and influence maximization.
Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that NodeTrix significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of efficiency and effectiveness.

In this work, we investigate how the equivalence principle (EP) is modified when quantum gravitational effects are taken into account. This principle states that all local physical laws should retain the same form in any freely falling reference frame.
Previous studies have shown that in general relativity with massive gravitons, the equivalence principle (EP) is violated [1].

In these theories, inflatons and/or axions appear as additional degrees of freedom beyond the graviton.
The inflaton directly couples with photons, while the axion couples indirectly through its coupling with photons and gluons. [5]

We found that the number of detectable systems within a given volume is closely related to the assumed binary parameter distribution functions, such as the mass ratio q = M2/M1 or the total system mass Mtot = M1 + M2.
This dependency arises because different distributions lead to significant differences in the proportion of binaries that are favorably oriented relative to the line of sight of the detector.
If the orientations of all binary star systems are random, then only about 10% of them will produce signals that exceed the detection threshold.
On the other hand, if they are prioritized towards the observer, this proportion will increase to 50%.
Therefore, it seems crucial to determine the true distribution function of these quantities through observation before making any predictions about the number of detections.

We use the Hamilton-Jacobi method to study circular and non-circular motion on the event horizon of rotating black holes. This method is an extension of the standard geodesic approach and takes into account higher-order corrections caused by the gravitational radiation reaction effect.
We found that for circular and non-circular motion, there are two types of solutions with different orbital frequencies at the same radius.
The orbital frequencies of the inner family are lower than those of the outer family; this corresponds to bound orbits, while the outer solution describes unbound orbits.
For circular orbits, we show how to derive these results directly from the first law of black hole thermodynamics.
In addition, we also provide numerical evidence indicating that as the spin parameter increases, the innermost stable circular orbit (ISCO) moves inward.
Finally, we discussed certain implications of our results for astrophysical phenomena, such as the accretion disk around a rotating black hole.

We study the stability properties of the Toda lattice under small periodic perturbations in time.
We prove that if the perturbation is sufficiently small, there exists an exponentially stable solution that can be found by solving a linear algebraic system.
The proof relies on Floquet theory and the Lyapunov-Schmidt reduction method.

This result generalizes the previous findings obtained in undisturbed systems where there is only one equilibrium point, or when there are two equilibrium points that are not connected by a heteroclinic trajectory.

Specifically, we prove that for any number of equilibrium points greater than 2 (including infinitely many), there exists an arbitrarily large perturbation such that all solutions of the perturbed system tend to infinity as \( t \to \infty \). A globular cluster is a dense system of stars, containing thousands to millions of stars, and is possibly one of the oldest known gravitationally bound objects.
The discovery of planets around other stars has raised the question of whether members of globular star clusters can also have planetary systems.
In this work, we use Monte Carlo simulations to study how many planets may exist in globular clusters of different masses and ages.

We found that under most reasonable assumptions about planet formation rates, every star should have at least one planet, except for the youngest (less than 10 million years) and lowest mass (less than 100 times the solar mass) clusters.
This result is robust against our uncertainty regarding the efficiency of planet formation and the initial conditions, such as the number density distribution of planetesimals.
Our results indicate that using existing observational techniques, planets orbiting members of globular clusters can be detected.
Keywords: planetary systems; stellar evolution; star clusters; formation.

We propose an extension of a cable model that allows for the consideration of neuronal membrane dynamics with active conductance across various timescales and spatial dimensions, including scales related to subthreshold electrogenic functions.
The proposed method is based on reconstructing the cable equation into a system of first-order differential equations that describe the voltage changes along an axon or dendrite.
This formula naturally leads to the generalization of the concept of spatial constants to include both the passive and active components of membrane impedance.
We demonstrate how this generalized cable form can be used to describe the propagation of action potentials through a single-chamber neuron under Hodgkin-Huxley type current.
Finally, we demonstrate its practicality by applying it to the study of spatiotemporal activity patterns in coupled neural networks.
Neurons are highly specialized cells that can generate electrical signals known as action potentials (APs).
These action potentials propagate along the axon of the cell to the synaptic terminal, where they trigger the release of neurotransmitters into the synapse.
These neurotransmitters bind sequentially to receptors located on the postsynaptic side, initiating a signal cascade that ultimately leads to the generation of a new action potential.
Therefore, the transmission of information between neurons is achieved through chemical synapses that propagate action potentials (AP).

We studied the dynamic behavior of silver atoms deposited on gold (100) through molecular dynamics simulations, investigating how it is affected by changes in substrate temperature and coverage, specifically when the average number of nearest neighbors per atom varies between 1 and 4.
We found that, for low coverage, the behavior of the system is like that composed of non-interacting isolated particles.

The results obtained indicate that these structures can be categorized into two types based on whether they are formed by a single layer or multiple layers of silver atoms.
In particular, we found that the structure of the first layer largely depends on the substrate temperature, while the second layer shows only minor variations.
Finally, our calculations indicate that the third layer has formed a disordered arrangement of silver atoms.

1 Introduction

In recent years, we have made considerable progress in understanding the physical processes occurring near supermassive black holes (SMBHs), which are found in active galactic nuclei (AGN), quasars, and other similar systems.
These studies rely on observations of the broadband spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of supermassive black holes over multiple decades in frequency space.
However, due to their vast distances, the intrinsic luminosity of most active galactic nuclei (AGN) cannot be measured directly.
On the contrary, people can use indirect methods, such as echo mapping or the statistical correlations between various active galactic nucleus (AGN) characteristics, to determine their brightness.
For example, if the amount of light passing through the region of interest in the active galactic nucleus is known, simple geometric reasoning can be used to calculate its brightness.
Alternatively, if the distance to an active galactic nucleus (AGN) is known, its absolute magnitude can be measured directly.
Unfortunately, both methods require a detailed understanding of the structure of the radiative zone, and this information is currently unavailable through observation.

Therefore, in order to accurately estimate the brightness of distant active galactic nuclei, it is necessary to develop models that can reproduce the spectral energy distribution (SED) observed in nearby active galactic nuclei.

We present the results of a study on the physical characteristics of polar broad absorption line quasi-stellar objects (BALQSOs).
We found that BAL QSOs are more likely to be radio-loud sources than non-BAL QSOs, and they have higher luminosities at rest-frame ultraviolet wavelengths.

The proportion of BALQSOs in our sample is consistent with previous studies; however, we did not find any significant differences, indicating that there is no variation in the proportion of BALQSOs between radio-quiet and radio-loud quasars.
Through addition, we found no evidence of differences in the attributes of BALs observed from different viewpoints in individual objects.
Finally, we demonstrate a correlation between the intensity of the blue shift in the CIV emission line and the equivalent width of the associated BAL troughs.
These research findings indicate that BALQSO may represent a special class of radio-loud quasars characterized by a high accretion rate onto supermassive black holes.

We present results from direct cosmological hydrodynamic simulations that investigate the formation of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) at the centers of galaxies, their evolution over time after merging with other supermassive black holes, and the feedback this evolution has on the characteristics of galaxies.
We found that at z = 0, the simulated supermassive black hole (SMBH) mass function is very consistent with observational results for M• > 10^7M_solar.

At higher redshifts, our model predicts that the number of low-mass supermassive black holes is greater than the observational estimates based on the quasar luminosity function; this discrepancy may be due to uncertainties in the assumed quasar duty cycle or radiative efficiency.
Our model predicts an average Eddington ratio distribution that is consistent with the observed distribution inferred from optical/ultraviolet emission lines.

In addition, we demonstrate that the predicted relationship between black hole mass and the dispersion of bulge velocity is in good agreement with observational results across a range of black hole masses spanning four orders of magnitude.
We propose to use Hierarchical Hidden Markov Random Fields (HHMRFs) as the foundational model in an unsupervised segmentation algorithm for hyperspectral images.
HHMRFs are constructed by combining layers of multiple hidden Markov chains, with each layer associated with a specific spatial scale.
We demonstrate that this multi-scale approach can provide better performance than the single-scale method, and we validate its effectiveness on two different datasets.
Finally, we compare our results with those obtained using state-of-the-art algorithms based on Gaussian mixture models or sparse coding techniques.

We proposed a new model of non-Abelian string networks, based on the idea that the network is composed of many intertwined strings with different speeds and directions.

Specifically, we consider two types of diagrams: (i) ladder diagrams, corresponding to gluon exchanges between different strings, and (ii) crossed ladder diagrams, describing interactions among three or more strings.

We present the results of our analysis of the impact of cosmic rays on galaxy clusters, using both cosmological hydrodynamic simulations with and without cosmic rays.

We found that the presence of cosmic rays leads to an increase in gas temperature at large radii (r > 0.5Rvir), which is caused by adiabatic compression of the cluster environment (ICM) during the formation of the cluster.

The measurement of ultra-low potassium contamination in silicon is very important for the development and production of semiconductor devices, especially solar cells.
Traditional methods such as flame photometry or atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS) have detection limits that are insufficient to meet industry standards.
From this work, we propose an alternative method based on Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (AMS).
We demonstrated that AMS can be used to measure potassium concentrations as low as 10^(-12) atomic percent in silicon samples.
This corresponds to an increase in sensitivity by three orders of magnitude compared to standard techniques such as flame photometry.
In addition, our results indicate that there is no significant matrix effect in AMS when measuring low potassium-doped silicon wafers.
Finally, we discuss the potential applications of AMS beyond being a high-sensitivity analytical tool.

We present recent near-infrared (NIR) and millimeter-wave observations of the interstellar dense core FeSt 1-457, which is located in the Taurus molecular cloud complex, approximately 140 parsecs away from Earth.

No significant emission line features were observed in either spectrum.

Megapie (Mega Voltage Ionization Projection Imaging Experiment) is an experiment aimed at researching the feasibility and performance of proton radiography in medical applications.

The main objective of this project is to develop a compact high-intensity ion source based on laser-plasma interactions, in order to generate protons with energies of up to several hundred mega-electron volts.

We studied the thick brane model, in which our universe is embedded in an extra dimension, and found that it can explain some recent observational results, such as the cosmic microwave background anisotropies, Type Ia supernova data, and baryon acoustic oscillations, without introducing new physics beyond the standard model.

We propose an efficient data redistribution scheme that enables parallel execution of dynamically resizable computation domains in a distributed memory environment.

We studied the scattering characteristics of surface plasmons (SPs) induced by a single subwavelength groove in optically thick metallic films, which are excited by normally incident circularly polarized plane waves.
The distribution of the SP field and its attenuation length under different values of slot depth hg and slot width wg was calculated using the Green's function method.

The research found that when the groove depth increases to a certain value, the field of surface plasmons (SP) exhibits exponential decay in two directions at the center of the groove, rather than being confined to the groove area as before.
This phenomenon can be explained by the following fact: once the surface wave mode is scattered into a radiative mode through the groove opening, it becomes leaky.

We also found that there is another critical channel depth; beyond this depth, due to total internal reflection between the channel walls, surface wave fields cannot exist inside or outside the channel.
These results provide useful information for designing efficient plasma devices based on grooves.
We present new observational results for the low surface brightness galaxy PGC 045080, which is known to host an active galactic nucleus (AGN).

Introduction  
A graph G = (V, E) consists of two sets V and E, where V represents the set of vertices or nodes, and E represents the set of edges connecting pairs of nodes.
The edge \( e = (u, v) \) connects node \( u \in V \) and node \( v \in V \).
If such a connection does not exist, then e is not included in E. The path P is defined as a series of distinct nodes v1, v2, …, vn, such that for i = 2, 3, …, n, we have vi−1vi ∈ E.
A loop C is defined as a path where the starting node and the ending node are the same.

A connected component is a subgraph H of graph G with the property that any pair of nodes in H can be connected by a path within H, but cannot be connected by a path outside of H. A clique K is a complete subgraph of G; that is to say, every pair of nodes in K is connected to each other.
A k-clique is a clique composed of exactly k nodes.
A vertex cover S is a subset of V such that every edge in the graph G has at least one endpoint in S.
A dominating set \( D \) is a subset of \( V \).

We propose a multi-mode nested sampling (MNS), a novel algorithm capable of efficiently exploring the posterior distribution of high-dimensional parameter spaces, such as those encountered when fitting complex models to observational datasets.
MNS combines the principles of simulated annealing with importance sampling techniques to find the global maximum likelihood solution within a given tolerance range.

We demonstrated how to apply this method to real-world problems by applying it to two different astrophysics cases: using time-dependent models to simulate the observed flux of gamma-ray bursts; and determining the parameters of binary black hole merger events detected through gravitational waves.
In these two cases, we demonstrate that our new method outperforms the existing Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithms.
The code to implement these examples will be publicly published at https://github.com/mns-method/mns-method/tree/master/examples.

Multimodal Nested Sampling (MNS) is a novel algorithm capable of exploring posterior distributions in high-dimensional parameter spaces, which often arise when fitting complex models to large observational datasets.
It combines simulated annealing and importance sampling techniques to find the global maximum likelihood solution for any problem within a specified tolerance.

This lecture describes the basic principles of MNS and demonstrates its application to two astrophysical problems: simulating the observed light curves of gamma-ray bursts, and inferring the physical properties of binary black hole systems from gravitational wave observations.
The WiFeS instrument is an integral field spectrograph located on the 2.3-meter telescope at the Australian National University's Siding Spring Observatory in Australia.
Since its commissioning in 2005, the equipment is designed to provide high-quality spectral analysis across a wide wavelength range, with the lowest operational costs.

The WiFeS instrument consists of two cameras mounted on a common base, which is located in the vacuum chamber connected to the Cassegrain focus of the 2.3-meter telescope at the Australian National University.
Each camera contains a lens array that can generate a set of images on its focal plane.
These images can be combined into a single data cube using the software developed by Dopita et al. (2007).
This data cube provides information about the spatial positions and wavelengths of each line of sight for the observed objects.

In addition to this capability, WiFeS offers several other advantages, including: - High throughput due to the use of a dichroic beam splitter and optical fiber coupling between the lens and the detector.
Flexible observation modes, from fully automated observations to manual control via remote desktop interface.
Quick reading of the time allows multiple targets to be observed simultaneously or to quickly switch between different targets during an evening of observation.
Low maintenance requirements, as it does not require any moving parts within the vacuum enclosure.
The excellent stability is attributed to the design of the optical platform and the thermal isolation provided by the vacuum casing.
Large format detector arrays can provide excellent signal-to-noise ratios even under poor observation conditions.
Robust mechanical design to ensure long-term reliability.

The authors used scanning tunneling microscopy to investigate the surface structure and electronic properties of the high-temperature copper oxide superconductor Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8+d (Bi-2212) single crystals.
They found that at low temperatures, this material forms hole pairs that are bound together by phonon-mediated attractive interactions.
The binding energy is approximately 0.5 electron volts per pair of holes.

We present new experimental results on the relaxation dynamics of liquid films, which are pulled up from an inclined solid substrate by gravity and capillary action.
The experiment was conducted in the microgravity environment of the International Space Station (ISS).
We found that, for sufficiently large stretching speeds, the relaxation process can be described as a continuous process of three stages.
In the first stage, the contact angle rapidly drops to its equilibrium value, at which point the contact line stops moving.
Phase II begins when the contact line stops moving; during this phase, the contact angle remains constant while the height profile of the free surface continues to evolve towards its final shape.
Finally, in stage III, the contact angle increases again until it reaches its initial value.
This behavior can be explained by a simple model based on lubrication theory.
Our analysis shows that the relaxation time is inversely proportional to the stretching speed.
Under low tension, we observed deviations from our theoretical predictions due to inertial effects.

We present optical and near-infrared photometric measurements of SN 2006bp, which was discovered on September 24, 2006, in NGC 6946 by amateur astronomer Brian P. Pakett (Pakett et al., 2007).
This supernova is located at an unusually far distance from its host galaxy, with a velocity of about 1000 kilometers per second.

We present the results of the analysis of the effects of stellar surface structure in high-precision spatial optical astronomical measurements, which are expected to be realized by future space missions such as Gaia and SIM.
We indicate that these effects will lead to systematic errors in the derived parameters of individual stars, with an accuracy reaching below 1 microarcsecond (mas).
The main sources of error include the limb darkening effect, the gravitational brightening effect, and the rotational distortion effect.
These effects largely depend on the spectral type of the observed stars.
For example, we find that the rotational distortion shapes of late-type giants may cause significant shifts in their positions at different measurement times, reaching up to several milli-arcseconds.
This is comparable to, or even higher than, the accuracy targets set for the Gaia mission.
Therefore, when analyzing the data obtained from future space missions, it is necessary to take these influences into account.

We present new measurements of line emissions from the brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) in galaxy clusters with redshift z < 0.3, obtained using the Chandra X-ray Observatory.

We found a strong correlation between the optical luminosity of BCG and its soft X-ray luminosity; this correlation is stronger than the previously reported correlations between optical and radio luminosity or optical and infrared luminosity.
The observed relationship can be explained if we assume that most of the X-rays originate from the reverse Compton scattering of thermal electrons associated with the central supermassive black hole.
This result indicates that there may be an evolutionary connection between active galactic nuclei and large galaxy clusters.

In addition to the strong correlation between Lopt and LX, we also observed a weak but significant negative correlation between Lopt and the temperature Tgas of the interstellar medium surrounding each galaxy.
These results indicate that the gas density around these galaxies decreases as they evolve into higher mass systems.
The Fermi Large Area Telescope (LAT) is the main instrument of the Fermi satellite launched by NASA in June 2008, aimed at studying high-energy gamma rays and cosmic rays.
LAT has been collecting data since August 4, 2008, and has been in continuous operation to this day.
This presentation will highlight the latest results obtained by the LAT collaboration using this unique dataset.

These include new measurements of the high-energy diffuse extragalactic background light, constraints on dark matter annihilation models, and studies of quasars as potential sources of ultra-high-energy cosmic rays.
I will also discuss and analyze some challenges associated with such large-scale datasets.
Finally, I will briefly describe the observation plans that can be carried out in the future using LAT.
Keywords: high-energy astrophysics, dark matter, quasars, ultra-high-energy cosmic rays, diffuse cosmic background light.

We present the results of searching for gravitational wave signals from compact binary coalescences (CBCs) using data collected during the third and fourth scientific runs (S3, S4) of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO).

We use two different search methods to observe gravitational wave sources from coalescing binary compact objects (CBCs): one is a model-agnostic matched filtering method that is sensitive to all possible source directions, and the other is a template bank method based on the post-Newtonian expansion of general relativity.
The latter method has a higher sensitivity, but it only covers certain areas of the parameter space.
In this work, we report the upper limit on the event rate density of CBC events related to vortex mass and total mass.
These are derived based on the assumption that the observed event rate follows Poisson statistics with no background noise.

For these two search methods, we obtained the strictest upper limits under high-quality conditions, as the signal-to-noise ratio rapidly decreases due to the influence of the detector's antenna response function.
We proposed an analytical model to study the impact of quality loading feedback on particle concentration and vorticity in fully developed turbulence.
The cascade process is modeled through a set of coupled ordinary differential equations, which are derived based on dimensional analysis and the Kolmogorov similarity hypothesis.
We demonstrate that the presence of particles can significantly affect the energy transfer rate between different scales as well as the dissipation rate at smaller scales.
Specifically, we found that when there is significant mass loading feedback, the total energy quantity reduces when transitioning to smaller scales.
This result indicates that the presence of heavy particles may lead to a reduction in turbulent mixing efficiency.
Finally, our results also indicate that if the Stokes number increases or the initial volume fraction of the particles increases, the impact of mass loading feedback becomes more pronounced.
Our research findings provide valuable insights that help understand how heavy particles affect the dynamics of fluid flow.

We present the results of an anisotropy analysis of the distribution of satellite galaxies around isolated field galaxies, using data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).
We found that there is no significant difference in the distribution of satellite galaxies with different brightness or colors compared to those surrounding the central galaxy.

This indicates that these effects may be responsible for the formation of galaxy clusters and groups.

1 Introduction  
Galaxy clusters contain thousands of galaxies that are located within a common dark matter halo.
These systems are formed by gravitational collapse caused by the mutual attraction between their constituent galaxies.
However, it is still unclear how this process occurs on the timescale from the interaction of individual galaxies to that of large galaxy clusters containing hundreds of member galaxies.
In particular, we do not know whether all galaxies will evolve into members of large star clusters, or whether some will remain as isolated field galaxies throughout the history of the universe.

2 Previous Work

Reid et al., 1991; Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; York et al., 2000).
They found that the number density profile of the satellite galaxies shows a significant deviation from sphericity, indicating that they are distributed anisotropically around their host galaxies.
Additionally, they show that the degree of anisotropy largely depends on the projected distance from the center of the host galaxy.
At short distances, the radial profile shows a steep decline at the center of the host, while the tangential component increases rapidly beyond the characteristic radius R.

The impact temperature of molybdenum is determined by measuring the resistance of the sample subjected to impact under pressures of up to 1000 kilobars (1 Mbar).
The release temperature is measured using an optical infrared thermometer, and the sample is heated with a laser beam after being subjected to impacts at different pressures.
The impact generated by the pulse power supply is used to compress the sample material between two electrodes.
The voltage pulses applied between these electrodes cause a flow of current in the compressed material, resulting in Joule heating.
The increased heat raises the material's resistivity, causing it to expand rapidly until the temperature exceeds the Curie point.
As this expansion occurs, the resistance decreases significantly, resulting in a sharp increase in the current flowing into the sample.
When the current reaches the critical value, the sample explodes, releasing most of the stored energy.
The explosion also destroyed one or two electrodes, so further measurements cannot be made until new electrodes are installed.

In order to understand how galaxies evolve over time, it is important to accurately know their distances.
However, accurate distances are difficult to measure, as they largely depend on the assumed luminosity evolution model.
For example, if we assume an excessively high rate of luminosity evolution, the derived distance will be underestimated.
On the other hand, if we assume that the rate of luminosity evolution is too low, then the derived distances may be overestimated.
Therefore, before deriving the distance to any galaxy, it is essential to determine the correct luminosity evolution model.
One way to solve this problem is to use a radio source whose distance can be independently determined by other means.
These include pulsars, quasars, and microwave laser sources associated with star-forming regions.
Among these objects, microwave self-excited sources are used most frequently because they provide very precise distance estimates.

In isolated systems, the study of equilibrium fluctuations employs statistical mechanics and information theory.
The entropy production rate is calculated for different types of isolated systems: (i) closed systems, (ii) open systems, and (iii) dissipative systems.
Research indicates that the rate of entropy production can be expressed as the sum of transitions between all possible states, weighted by their respective transition probabilities.
For a closed system, it is found to be equal to zero at thermal equilibrium.
This result is very consistent with the results obtained earlier in the linear response theory.
In contrast, for open or dissipative systems, we find that even when they reach thermal equilibrium, the rate of entropy production does not vanish.
We demonstrate how this finding leads to a new interpretation of the second law of thermodynamics.
Finally, we discuss our findings from the perspective of the fluctuation theorem.

The ζ function is a major object in number theory and algebraic geometry.
In this lecture, I will explain how to utilize it to study quantum field theory in curved spacetimes with nontrivial topology.

The basic idea is to consider the Feynman path integral for all fields in spacetime, treating it as an infinite-dimensional functional integral, and then regularizing it by replacing the space of fields with a finite-dimensional vector space equipped with an appropriate norm.
This naturally leads to the concept of "quantum theoretical elements," where the ζ function encodes information about the spectrum of the corresponding quantum field theory (QFT).
We can also discuss some recent results concerning the relationship between the ζ functions of certain families of quantum rings and their related modular forms.
Quantum field theory (QFT) has developed into a powerful tool for studying physical phenomena, capable of probing down to the most fundamental level.
However, due to the difficulties of performing calculations outside of perturbation theory, many interesting problems remain unsolved.
One way to solve these difficulties is to apply concepts from mathematics, such as ideas from number theory or algebraic geometry.
We are particularly interested in using the so-called "ζ function" of algebraic varieties to gain new insights into quantum field theory.
These objects encode important information about fundamental physics, but they are notoriously difficult to handle in explicit calculations.

In recent years, there has been increasing interest in developing efficient solutions to problems related to computational complexity theory, such as the graph isomorphism problem.
The purpose of this question is to determine whether the given two graphs are isomorphic; that is to say, whether they have the same structure regardless of their labels.
The classic approach to solving Geographic Information Problems (GIP) typically relies on a combination of random walk techniques and some heuristic methods.
However, these methods require exponential time in the worst case.
On the other hand, quantum algorithms provide polynomial time solutions for many NP-complete problems, including GIP.
These algorithms utilize the principle of superposition, allowing them to explore all possible states simultaneously.
For example, Shor's algorithm solves integer factorization in polynomial time, while Grover's search finds any item in a database in square root time.
We study the thermodynamic and transport properties of the Kondo necklace model (KNM) near its quantum phase transition to the ordered state, which is driven by spin fluctuations.
We demonstrate that this transformation can be described within the framework of the Landau-Ginzburg-Wilson theory, featuring a non-trivial order parameter field with scaling dimensions.
The latter determines the universal categories of transformation and the temperature dependence of various physical quantities, such as specific heat or resistivity.

I. Introduction Remarks
The Kondo necklace model describes a series of magnetic impurity chains coupled by antiferromagnetic exchange interaction J.
It was originally used to describe the physics of heavy fermion compounds, but it also naturally appears in other contexts.
In this study, we consider the case where the coupling constant J exceeds a certain critical value.
The equation \( J_c = \frac{2t}{U} \) indicates that \( t \) represents the hopping amplitude between adjacent sites, and \( U \) represents the local Coulomb repulsion energy 8-10.

At temperatures below zero degrees, the ground state of the system corresponds to a ferromagnetically ordered state. However, at finite temperatures, one would expect a continuous quantum phase transition to occur, transitioning to a paramagnetic state.
This transition occurs due to strong spin fluctuations, and thus belongs to the same universality class as the Heisenberg chain.

However, there are important differences between these two models 24-26: first, the Kondo chain contains two types of excitations — spinons and holons 27-29 — while the Heisenberg chain is composed solely of spin-1/2 particles.
Secondly, the Kondo necklace includes additional degrees of freedom associated with charge carriers.
These features have triggered new phenomena in the Heisenberg chain that have not been observed.
For example, the Kondo necklace system may exhibit unconventional superconducting states.

Finally, we discussed potential directions for extending our results beyond the case of free fermions.

We present the orbital evolution results of Jupiter and Saturn embedded in an axisymmetric, viscous evolving protoplanetary disk.

1 Introduction  
Planets are formed through a condensation process from dust particles (Safronov 1969; Wetherill & Stewart 1989), followed by an uncontrolled accumulation process occurring on these growing bodies (Lissauer 1987).
This process led to the formation of planetary material, with masses ranging from \(10^{-6} M_{\oplus}\) to several Earth masses.

If these celestial bodies accumulate enough material in a short period of time, they can further grow into larger planetary embryos, or even directly evolve into gas giants like Jupiter and Saturn (Pollack et al. 1996).
Once formed, these giant planets open gaps in the surrounding protoplanetary disk due to the tidal torques exerted by planetary gravity (Lin & Papaloizou 1986).

Therefore, the remaining material within this gap will be quickly removed due to viscous effects, resulting in the rapid inward migration of the planet, which is classified as type II migration (Ward 1997; Tanaka et al. 2002).

The observed distribution of exoplanets shows a wide variety of orbital configurations, ranging from circular orbits around Sun-like stars to highly eccentric orbits around low-mass stars (see, for example, Marcy et al. (2005), Udry & Santos 2007, Winn et al. (2010), Johnson et al. (2011), and the references within).
However, the vast majority of the exoplanets that have been discovered are located close to their parent stars, as strong stellar radiation significantly increases the likelihood of detection.
We report an attempt to detect the thermal radiation of the planet TrES-1 using data obtained from the infrared array camera (IRAC) on the Spitzer Space Telescope.

We did not find significant radiation emitted by this planet in the infrared radiation at wavelengths longer than 3 micrometers, and we set the upper limit of its temperature between 1000 K and 1500 K based on assumptions about its albedo.
These results are consistent with previous estimates based solely on optical photometry.

The lack of detectable infrared radiation indicates that either the planet has almost no atmosphere, or its surface pressure is very low, which may be due to the planet being tidally locked and rotating synchronously.

The Missing Satellite Problem (MSP) is one of the most important issues in space science and technology, with applications ranging from satellite navigation to space debris removal.
The MSP requires orbits that are stable under the gravitational perturbations of known celestial bodies (such as planets or asteroids).

From this work, we propose an algorithm that can solve the MSP (Maximum Satisfiability Problem) exactly in any dimension d >= 2, with a required time of O(n log n + m log n), where n = |S| is the total number of objects in S and m = |E| is the number of edges in E. Our approach combines several novel techniques, including fast matrix multiplication algorithms, interval tree-based data structures, and efficient graph traversal methods.
We also demonstrated how to use our results to address related problems, such as finding the minimum distance between two given point sets in R^d.

The information-based asset pricing model is an extension of the traditional Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM), incorporating additional factors in its analysis.

The first factor, the market risk premium, represents the excess return that investors require for holding risky assets, which exceeds the return they receive from low-risk investments (such as treasury bills or bonds).
The second factor, scale effect, captures the difference in expected returns between small-cap stocks and large-cap stocks.

The third factor, the value effect, measures the difference in returns between stocks with high book-to-market ratios and those with low book-to-market ratios. Research shows that this factor is particularly important during periods of falling interest rates.
This article briefly outlines these three factors and provides examples of how they influence investment decisions.
The Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) was developed by Sharpe (1964), Lintner (1965), Mossin (1966), and Black (1972), and it is one of the most widely used models in today's financial field.

It explains that the expected return of any given security should be equal to the sum of two components: the risk-free rate plus the risk premium associated with the inherent level of systematic risk of each security.

In other words, if you hold a portfolio that consists solely of risk-free securities, your expected return will only be the risk-free rate; however, if you hold a diversified portfolio that includes both risky securities and risk-free securities, your expected return will increase proportionally with the level of risk you take on.
For example, let's assume we have a hypothetical investor whose portfolio consists of 50% U.S. Treasury bonds and 50% S&P 500 index funds.

The problem addressed here is data association - given two sets of observed data (for example, images), determine which pairs correspond to the same physical object.

This issue often arises when dealing with objects from multiple perspectives, as shown in Figure 1. In such cases, due to calibration errors, occlusions, and other reasons, perfect alignment between the two images may not always be achievable.

In many applications, prior knowledge about the correspondence between two sets of observations exists; for example, if they are captured using the same sensor but at different times, then their relative poses will be known, but there is a scaling factor involved.
The goal is to use this information to improve the accuracy of the final solution in these situations.
Our approach relies on the concept of "true clustering":
The true clustering is a set of points in a high-dimensional space that are close to each other while being far from other points in the space.
For example, consider the situation involving two images that register a scene with several people standing next to each other.
"Everyone forms their own real cluster because their appearance does not change significantly over time."
On the other hand, the background is changing rapidly, so there is no single cluster that can correspond to the entire background area.
Given two sets of true clusters corresponding to the first and second observations, we want to find the best allocation between them.
To achieve this, we define a cost function based on the point distances between each pair of actual clusters.
Then, we formulate the problem as a quadratic integer programming problem and solve it efficiently using the branch and bound technique.

The relationship between body size (mass) and brain size in animals is known as allometric growth, but it is currently unclear how this relationship has evolved.
Specifically, there are two competing hypotheses that explain why large animals have a larger brain capacity than small animals.

The first hypothesis suggests that larger animals need to process more information about their environment; the second hypothesis suggests that larger animals require better coordination between different parts of their bodies.
Here, we use size data of the brains and bodies of mammals of different sizes (from mice to elephants) to test these hypotheses against each other.

We found evidence supporting both hypotheses simultaneously—larger animals may indeed need to process more information, but they also need to coordinate activities across multiple areas of the body and require greater precision.
Our results indicate that the evolutionary pressure to increase brain size may be related to the ability of animals with larger brains to integrate information spatially and temporally.

The propagation model describes how cosmic rays spread through space via a diffusion process, accompanied by energy loss due to interactions with interstellar gas particles caused by ionization and Coulomb scattering.

Cosmic rays have been observed since the 19th century.

We proposed an algorithm for unicast and multicast quality of service (QoS) routing on the internet using Soft Constraint Logic Programming (SCLP).
The proposed method is based on the concept that each node maintains its own view of the network topology, which may differ from the views of other nodes due to link failures or congestion.
We use SCLP as our foundational framework because it naturally represents the inconsistent information between nodes.
In addition, we demonstrate how to incorporate bandwidth constraints into the SCLP model by introducing a new variable that represents the available bandwidth between two adjacent links.

Magnetic reconnection is one of the most important processes for understanding many phenomena observed in plasmas in space and laboratory settings, such as solar flares, magnetospheric substorms, and sawtooth crashes in tokamaks.
From this work, we proposed an analytical model that describes the magnetic reconnection process with arbitrary initial conditions in a collisionless high-energy plasma.
The main idea of our method is to utilize the concept of the generalized force density tensor (GDFT) introduced in MHD theory.
We indicate that GDFT can be used not only to describe macrodynamics but also to describe the microscopic properties of the system, such as the particle distribution function.
We compared our results with those obtained from other methods based on the kinetic energy of particle motion.

The results show that when these models are applied to the simple case with no gradient in the direction perpendicular to the background magnetic field at the initial state, the predictions they provide are similar.
However, if there exists some gradient between the magnetic field lines, then different models will predict completely different behaviors.

We reported a study on dynamic ion simulation aimed at exploring whether ion trapping would enhance the reflectivity of stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS) in the presence of an electron beam and plasma waves.

We found that for typical parameters related to high-power laser-plasma experiments, backward Brillouin scattering is primarily dominated by the instability of electrostatic Langmuir waves rather than by ion acoustic modes.

We propose a method to quantify how much evolutionary history could be lost if specific species were to become extinct, and use this information to prioritize conservation measures.

We indicate that by considering both taxonomic diversity and phylogenetic diversity in conservation planning, it may be more effective in protecting a greater amount of biodiversity than using either measure alone.
The extinction of any single species not only means the disappearance of that species itself but also signifies the loss of all unique genetic variations within that lineage.
This may have significant impacts on ecosystem functions and other aspects of biodiversity, such as taxonomy or community composition.
However, there are many ways to define "biodiversity," each emphasizing different components of biological systems.
To effectively protect biodiversity, it may be necessary to consider a combination of multiple measures rather than focusing solely on one aspect.
Here, we propose a new method for measuring the amount of evolutionary history represented by a set of taxa (such as species), based on the relationships inferred from molecular data.

Our method utilizes the concept of "evolutionary uniqueness"—which describes the uniqueness of each taxonomic unit in relation to other taxonomic units in terms of shared evolutionary history—to calculate the expected contribution of a single species to the overall phylogenetic diversity.

By combining these values into a single index, we obtained a quantitative ranking that orders species according to their importance in the evolutionary history of specific taxonomic groups for conservation.
Using a simulated dataset, we demonstrated that our proposed metrics outperform existing methods in identifying key species that protect phylogenetic diversity.
Finally, we applied our method to evaluate the vulnerability of amphibian species to the impacts of climate change.

We present the results of the analysis of magnetic field evolution, temperature changes, and plasma flow speed observed by Hinode/SOT/SP (Solar Optical Telescope Spectropolarimeter) during the solar activity minimum period from September 24 to 25, 2007.
The active region NOAA 10930 was located at S19E09 and produced two flares, with GOES classifications of M5.7 and M1.0 respectively.
We found that there were significant changes in the photospheric magnetic field before and after these solar flares occurred.
Specifically, we detected a new magnetic flux emergence event that occurred approximately one hour before the first flash.
This newly emerging flux has led to the formation of a coronal hole above the active region.

We present new results on the luminosity function (LF) weak-end slope and evolution of optically selected quasars in the redshift range 0.5 < z < 2.2, based on the VIMOS-VLT Deep Survey (VVDS).
We use two different methods to estimate the LF parameters for each redshift range: the 1/Vmax method and the maximum likelihood fitting technique.
Our best fit value is obtained by combining these two techniques with Monte Carlo simulation.

This may be due to the effects of incompleteness or bias introduced during the selection process.

We present some new results on the monotonicity, stability, and construction of central difference schemes for nonlinear hyperbolic conservation laws systems with nonlocal source terms.

We consider two types of source term models: one is a smoothing model, where the source term can be represented as an integral of past history; the other is a fractional step method, where the source term is handled implicitly by solving a set of ordinary differential equations at each time level.
The main idea behind our construction of stable numerical methods is based on the concept of entropy conservative fluxes recently proposed by Tadmor and others.
Specifically, we demonstrate that any scheme constructed using these entropy-conserving fluxes will automatically maintain positivity if certain conditions are met.
Finally, several examples are provided to illustrate the theoretical results obtained here.

The concept of crystal defects has been developed by the Russian school since the 1930s.
The main idea is that any crystal can be regarded as an elastic continuum with some local deviations with respect to its ideal structure, and these deviations are referred to as defects.
In this work, we briefly review the historical development of solid defect theory.
We also discussed the modern concepts of point defects (dislocations), line defects (twists), and continuous defects.
Finally, we illustrate how these ideas can be applied to different physical systems, such as liquid crystals or magnetic materials.
Defects play an important role in many areas of physics, including solid-state physics, condensed matter physics, and biology.
They naturally appear during phase transitions between ordered states, such as phase transitions occurring at the melting point or critical temperature.
For example, they may lead to plastic deformation of metal or glass materials.
On the other hand, defects play an important role in the macroscopic properties of solids, such as electrical conductivity or magnetization.

The solar chromosphere is an important component in our understanding of how the Sun operates and its impact on Earth. However, due to its tenuous nature, studying this region has been quite challenging. The Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) will be able to observe this area for the first time with unprecedented spatial resolution.
This lecture will discuss some scientific research that can be conducted using the ALMA telescope to observe the solar chromosphere.
The solar chromosphere is one of the most mysterious regions of the Sun.
It is located between the photosphere and the corona, playing a key role in the transfer of energy to the upper atmosphere.

However, due to its extremely low density, it was only recently possible to directly observe the chromosphere using high-resolution space telescopes, such as the Hinode Solar Optical Telescope (Hinode/SOT) and the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO/AIA).

In addition, ground-based observation stations have made significant progress in studying the Chromosphere through various techniques, including spectral polarization imaging, imaging spectroscopy, and speckle interferometry.
Despite these advancements, there are still many unresolved issues regarding the physical processes occurring inside color balls that need to be addressed.
For example, what causes the formation of dynamic structures such as sunspots?
How will the magnetic field influence the plasma dynamics in the corona?
What is the relationship between chromospheric heating mechanisms and coronal mass ejections?
These questions cannot be answered without a detailed understanding of the structure and dynamics of the color spheres.
To address these issues, we need new observational data with higher spatial resolution than ever before.
We proposed an algorithm to find the optimal hierarchical descriptors (OHD) that can serve as fingerprints in complex networks, such as social and biological systems.
OHDs represent network structures at different granular levels using a tree structure, where nodes represent sub-networks or clusters.

Finally, we demonstrated our method through several examples, including synthetic benchmark datasets and real-world networks.
Our results show that the proposed method provides a more accurate description than existing methods.

Keywords: Asteroseismology, rotation, binary stars, oscillation, frequency analysis, high-precision radial velocity, Alpha Centauri

Abstract: We report new results from asteroseismic analysis of the main-sequence F-type star Alpha Centauri A, which forms a close binary system with its cooler companion star B.

Our research is based on over four years of high-precision radial velocity measurement data collected by the HARPS instrument installed on the ESO 3.6-meter telescope at the La Silla Observatory in the Chilean Andes, along with photometric observations conducted simultaneously with the CoRoT space mission.

By applying the standard techniques used in asteroseismology, we detected multiple periodic signals in two datasets, including one signal whose periodicity corresponds exactly to the orbital period of the system.
This finding confirms the previous suggestion that the pulsation behavior of this star may be affected by the tidal effects caused by its companion star.
In addition, our analysis revealed another set of signals that correspond to cycles ranging from about 1 day to nearly 2 days.
These signals can be interpreted as being caused by the oscillation of p modes excited by rotational splitting in the convective envelopes of the stars.
Their existence provides strong support for the following hypothesis: The surface of Alpha Centauri A is formed by magnetic activities driven by generator processes operating within the troposphere.

We presented numerical results of the evolution of two different types of coronal mass ejections (CMEs) in an open magnetic field configuration, which are related to space weather applications.

The first type of coronal mass ejection (CME) is driven by the motions of the photosphere, which generate Alfvén waves at the base of the corona. These waves propagate upward into the corona and intensify into shock waves.

We analyzed the stability of planetary systems, where primordial planetesimals evolve under oligarchic domination, meaning they can scatter their neighbors out through gravitational interactions, but cannot scatter themselves.
We found that this process leads to the rapid growth of the maximum embryo until it reaches the isolation mass (i.e., the minimum mass needed for uncontrolled accretion to occur).
The system then evolves into a single planet or two planets of comparable mass, depending on the proximity of the initial conditions to instability.
This evolution is very different from what happens when all objects grow simultaneously; specifically, we show that even with the same initial conditions, multiple stable outcomes can occur.
Our results indicate that the formation of Earth-like planets may have gone through multiple stages, including a oligarchic stage, before finally reaching the state we observe today.
In addition, our research provides new insights into the origins of super-Earth planets.
The original planetary embryos form in the interstellar disks around young stars and undergo mutual gravitational interactions during their growth stage.
These interactions lead to orbital migration and dynamic instability, such as collisions between adjacent embryos.
If these processes occur frequently enough, eventually only one celestial body will survive at the end of the growth phase, leaving a planetary system composed of just one planet.
However, recent studies have shown that many planetary systems contain multiple planets, indicating that some mechanism must exist to prevent the complete destruction of the system.

Here, we study whether protoplanetary embryos follow a hierarchical evolutionary path, in which they first grow hierarchically through gravitational scattering and then undergo uncontrolled aggregation after the largest embryos reach their isolation mass.
Through numerical simulations, we have demonstrated that this scenario naturally explains the existence of multi-planet systems while also reproducing the characteristics of known exoplanets.

The results obtained were discussed in relation to recent experiments conducted at room temperature.

We present the results of our dynamical study of the M31 globular cluster, based on high-resolution spectra obtained from the VLT and Keck telescopes.

We found that all star clusters studied show evidence of rotating around their principal axis (with typical speeds of 100-200 kilometers per second), while among the eight objects, only two have significant internal velocity dispersions (around 50-100 kilometers per second).
The remaining six clusters are consistent with a completely non-scattering system.
This is surprising because these star clusters contain a large number of evolutionary stars that belong to the extended horizontal branch.
Our analysis indicates that this apparent contradiction can be explained by assuming that most of the cluster mass is located beyond the observable field of view.

These findings suggest that many globular clusters may not be completely relaxed dynamical systems as previously thought.
They also provide new insights into the formation history of globular star clusters.

The fossil record is full of examples of periodic extinction events, but it remains unclear whether these events are driven by external factors or caused by internal dynamics within the ecosystems.
Here we state that the biodiversity cycle can arise solely from the interactions between species and their environments, without the need to invoke additional mechanisms such as mass extinctions.
We use an agent-based model to simulate how communities evolve over time under different environmental conditions.
Our results indicate that biodiversity cycles may have played an important role in shaping the history of Earth's biosphere.
The fossil record contains many examples of periodic extinction events (1), which has led some researchers to propose that there must be an underlying periodicity to ecosystem processes (2).

However, it is still unclear what has caused this obvious pattern in the fossil record; one possibility is that periods of high diversity alternated with intervals during which many species went extinct simultaneously.
Furthermore, it is still unclear whether all observed biodiversity cycling patterns represent genuine periodic behavior or merely reflect random variation around a mean (5-7).
Here, we provide evidence that biodiversity cycles can spontaneously arise solely through ecological interactions, without the need for any additional mechanisms, such as mass extinctions.
To verify our hypothesis, we used an agent-based model to explore how communities evolve over time under different environmental pressures.
This method allows us to study how changes in community composition affect the abundance of populations across multiple trophic levels.
By running simulations with thousands of repeats using different parameter values, we are able to identify robust statistical features related to the biodiversity cycle.

We studied the vortex matter in the honeycomb (HC) and kagome (KC) pinning arrays using the time-dependent Ginzburg-Landau equation with periodic boundary conditions, which was numerically solved on a square lattice of size L = 256.

We found that the influence of HC and KC on vortex dynamics depends on their density n. At low densities, vortices are pinned by local defects in both HC and KC; however, they form an ordered structure only in HC, while no such structure is formed in KC.

Under high density, we observe two different phases in HC; one is a vortex molecular crystal state, where all vortices occupy a single position, while the other phase has a vortex plastic crystal structure, where some vortices remain in an unfixed state.
Relatively speaking, even at a very high defect density, such an ordered state does not exist in KC.
Our results indicate that the difference between HC and KC stems from the fact that each position in HC can support multiple vortices, while KC cannot.

We analyzed the characteristics of the rare, hot (effective temperature T_eff > 20,000 K), helium-rich subdwarf B (sdB) stars and extreme horizontal branch (EHB) stars observed in globular clusters, which are referred to as redshift stars or blue hook stars.
We demonstrate how these celestial bodies can be explained by the merger of two helium white dwarfs whose total mass exceeds the Chandrasekhar limit.

The merged object is expected to have a radius greater than its Roche lobe at all stages of the merging process, which will stably transfer mass to the companion star until the companion star fills its Roche lobe and begins to overflow.
This leads to a common envelope phase, during which most of the released orbital energy is used to expel the outer layers of the two stars into space.
After this stage, the system consists of a bare helium core and a thin hydrogen layer covering the top of the helium core.

If the initial masses of the components of the progenitor white dwarfs are close enough that their cores merge before reaching the Chandrasekhar limit, we expect the final product to be similar to a normal sdB star; otherwise, the final product will be greater than the Chandrasekhar limit.
We present the analysis results of the clustering characteristics of luminous red galaxies (LRGs) in the seventh data release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS DR7).
We used a sample consisting of 380,000 LRGs, with selection criteria of 0.4 < zphot < 1.0 and Mr < -21.5 + 5logh.
The angle correlation function of this sample is measured using the Landy & Szalay estimator on scales from 10' to 100'.

To explain the redshift space distortion, we measured the projected cross-correlation function \( w_p(r_p) \), where \( r_p = D_{\text{proj}} / [H(z) / H_0] \), with \( H(z) \) being the Hubble parameter at redshift \( z \), and \( H_0 \) being its value today.
These measurements were conducted in a series of transverse separations, corresponding to physical scales starting from 2 h^-1.
"In 20 h⁻¹ Mpc."
In addition, we also measured the two-point correlation function in real space using the methods developed by Eisenstein et al. (2007).

We introduce the concept of Generalized Conditional Random Fields (GCRFs) and demonstrate how they can be used to model arbitrary probability distributions for structured datasets, such as sequences or trees.
We propose an efficient algorithm that learns GCRF parameters through gradient descent on the log-likelihood objective function.

Finally, we demonstrate that our method can learn accurate models for several challenging sequence labeling tasks, including part-of-speech tagging in natural language processing and protein secondary structure prediction in bioinformatics.

Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) (Lafferty et al., 2001) are undirected graphical models that have been successfully applied to various problems involving sequential data, such as (Sha & Pereira, 2003).

In this work, we propose Generalized Conditional Random Fields (GCRFs), which are an extension of Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) that allow us to represent distributions over any structured dataset, such as sequences or trees.
The key idea of GCRFs is to use a set of latent variables to capture the dependencies between different parts of the input space.
This enables us to efficiently compute the partition function required for standard conditional random fields using dynamic programming techniques.
In addition, it also makes it possible to train GCRFs using gradient-based methods similar to those used for maximum entropy Markov models (MEMMs).
To evaluate the performance of our method, we apply it to two important applications: part-of-speech tagging.
We analyzed satellite systems, fossil groups (FGs), and galaxy clusters in the millennium simulation.
We found that FGs are rare celestial objects, with only 0.5% of all halos classified as this type at z=0.
The number density of FGs is consistent with observations of systems with Mvir > 10^13 M⊙/h.
However, we also found a group of low-quality FGs that have not yet been observed, but future surveys may make them detectable.

In addition to their rarity, FGs exhibit several other interesting characteristics compared to ordinary galaxy clusters: they are often located in larger dark matter halos; they have fewer bright central galaxies; and they show a higher velocity dispersion.
These results indicate that FGs can provide important constraints for models of galaxy formation and evolution.
This work is supported by the NASA project NAG5-10842.

We present a catalog of 75 circumnuclear regions (CNRs) of nearby active galactic nuclei, which were observed using the Advanced Camera for Surveys on the Hubble Space Telescope, as part of the Nearby Galaxies Survey Treasury project.

CNR is defined as the brightest circular aperture with a diameter of 2 kpc centered on each galaxy nucleus, and it is imaged through the F330W filter to select emission lines with wavelengths greater than 3000 Å.
We use this data to study the characteristics of nuclear starbursts, which drive active galactic nuclei (AGN) through their influence on the surrounding interstellar medium.
In addition, we also studied how the physical conditions within CNRs vary in different types of active galactic nuclei (AGN).
We found that the excess ultraviolet radiation of most stars in the sample is significantly higher than the levels expected based solely on the emissions from the stellar photosphere.
This excess can be explained by the extinction caused by young hot stars or dust.
For celestial bodies that possess both spectral optics and infrared imaging, we indicate that the excess ultraviolet light is primarily due to dust extinction, rather than young hot stars.
We present the results of the role played by the rho meson in the description of the pion electroproduction data obtained with the CLAS detector at the Jefferson Laboratory (JLab).
The analysis is conducted within the framework of effective field theory, where we use chiral perturbation theory to describe the interactions between mesons and nucleons up to next-to-leading order.
We then introduce vector meson degrees of freedom through hidden gauge invariance.
Specifically, we consider the contributions from one-loop diagrams that include rho mesons and tree-level processes mediated by rho mesons.

Our theoretical framework allows us to study neutral current reactions, such as elastic electron-proton scattering, or charged current reactions, such as the production of a single π meson from protons.
Using this model, we are able to simultaneously reproduce the experimental data of all these observations.
Finally, we discussed how our research findings can be used to extract information about the properties of the rho meson.
This work is supported by the U.S. Department of Energy under contract number DE-SC0012704. PACS number: 12.38.Mh
We reported on Suzaku observations of four active galactic nuclei (AGN) detected through the Swift/BAT survey, which are classified as "obscured AGN" with a column density greater than 10^24 cm^-2.
We found that these sources exhibit strong iron K line emission, and their line widths are broader than expected from thermal broadening at kT = 100 keV.
The observed spectral line profile can be well reproduced by a relativistic disk reflection model that includes the Compton scattering effect.
The results indicate that there is an additional component in the X-ray continuum, beyond the standard thin accretion disk around a supermassive black hole.
Additionally, we found that among the four objects, three have iron abundance ratios exceeding 1.5 times that of the solar value.
This indicates that the central engines of these obscured active galactic nuclei may be buried beneath thick layers of dust.
Finally, we discuss the possible origins of this new type of buried supermassive black hole based on our observational results.
We present new results on the distribution of loop widths in active regions observed at the TRACE 171 Å wavelength, with these data obtained during the peak of solar activity (from May to June 2001).
We found that the loops at different temperatures have similar width distributions, which can be well-fitted by a log-normal function.
The means of these distributions increase with the rise in temperature, as expected, reflecting the pressure balance between the plasma within the magnetic structure and its surrounding environment.
However, we also found that there is no significant difference between the width measured along a single loop and the width determined by the average profile of the entire active region.
This indicates that the apparent constancy of the ring width may be due to averaging effects rather than the inherent nature of the coronal structure.

In addition, we also demonstrate that the width observed from different perspectives does not significantly depend on the relationship between the angle of the line of sight and the direction perpendicular to the local magnetic field vector.
We have performed on-orbit focal length adjustment (IFA) of its onboard infrared camera using data obtained from the AKARI satellite in orbit.

The execution of the IFA is conducted by comparing the observed point spread function (PSF) with the PSF simulated based on ray tracing analysis, which is also one of the most accurate methods for determining the optimal focus position.
We found that even after completing the IFA, the point spread functions (PSFs) between different bands are not always consistent.
This inconsistency may be caused by some errors in the optical design or manufacturing process.
In addition, we found that there are still some issues with the calibration accuracy of the detector's pixel size.
These results will help us better understand the performance of the instrument and provide useful information for future space missions.
Keywords: space missions, focal length adjustment, point spread function, ray tracing analysis, infrared astronomy, infrared camera.

We present the first results of deep infrared (IR) observations in the field of sculptor galaxy clusters, using ISOCAM at 12 microns, ISO at 15 microns, ESO-VLT/VISIR at 11.7 microns, and Spitzer/MIPS at 24 microns.
These data are used to study the evolution of galaxies over the past 8 billion years and their contribution to the extragalactic background light (EBL).
We found that the infrared luminosity function shows significant evolution between z = 0.5-0.8 and today.

Under high redshift conditions, we detected that the number density of bright infrared galaxies (LIRGs), ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs), and active galactic nuclei (AGNs) exceeds that of the local sample.
This is consistent with previous research based on optical/NIR surveys.
However, only a few objects in our sample can be classified as LIRGs or ULIRGs according to the standard criteria.
On the contrary, most sources show very large dust extinction values A(V) > 10 mag.
These sources have not been discovered to this day because they were not detected in optical/near-infrared surveys due to heavy obscuration.
In addition, we found a large amount of evidence for strong extinction in early-type galaxies present in these sources.

We present the results of flame evolution during the explosion of Type Ia supernovae (SN), based on two-dimensional hydrodynamic simulations that incorporate a detailed nuclear reaction network, applicable to both deflagration and detonation scenarios.

We found that the transition to detonation is triggered by shock-induced turbulent mixing at a density of about \(10^{9}\) g/cm\(^3\). The resulting detonation wave traverses the entire white dwarf within approximately 1 second after ignition.

At lower central density values, the explosion fails to produce enough 56Ni to explain the observational results.
