We proposed an algorithm that starts from the vacuum solution and adds a scalar field to generate new solutions to the coupled Einstein-scalar field equations, such that the final solution takes on the minimal coupling form.

The method can be used to generate exact solutions either for unknown explicit functions or for functions that are represented implicitly by certain parameters (for example, by solving algebraic equations).

We illustrate our method through multiple examples, including Schwarzschild-de Sitter black holes, Reissner–Nordström–anti-de Sitter black holes, Kerr–Newman–anti-de Sitter black holes, and charged expanding black holes.

Introduction: Exact solutions play an important role in theoretical physics, as they allow us to test various physical perspectives against concrete predictions.
However, finding the exact solution to physically interesting problems is often very difficult.
For example, after the discovery of general relativity, it took more than 100 years to find the first exact solution for a black hole.
Even today, there are still many unresolved questions about black holes.
One reason why finding exact solutions is particularly challenging is that most of the theories of interest do not acknowledge any simple analytic solutions.
Another issue arises when attempting to find solutions that describe systems with multiple interacting components, such as black holes surrounded by matter or other fields.

Here, it is often necessary to solve complex differential equations through numerical methods, which makes it difficult to find all possible solutions, even though the existence of a solution is theoretically guaranteed.

This situation is particularly severe when studying strongly coupled phenomena, as the reliability of numerical methods decreases in such cases, mainly due to significant corrections from higher-order terms of perturbation theory.

We analyzed the redshifts of two groups of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) with different brightness and found evidence of intrinsic redshift components in both.
The first sample consists of 12 Seyfert galaxies, which are bright active galactic nuclei (AGN) with broad emission lines.

We analyzed the accuracy of recovering gravitational wave (GW) signals emitted by merging binary stars through various approximate schemes using matched filtering techniques, particularly when these techniques are applied to simulated detector noise.

We provided an exact solution for the scattering problem of N layers of parallel layers under normal incidence, where these layers are separated by real space gaps or gradual barriers.

We derived an explicit expression for the reflection coefficient and the phase difference between adjacent layers.
These results are used to calculate the optical properties of periodic structures, such as Bragg reflectors and photonic crystals.

I. Introduction Note
The purpose of this study is to develop a unified theory to describe wave propagation in multilayer structures composed of alternating layers of different materials.
This includes periodic (photonic) and non-periodic (superlattice-like) layer arrangements.
We mainly focus on calculating the reflection coefficient and transmission coefficient, as well as the phase changes that occur as we pass through each individual layer.
As will be made clear below, these quantities provide all the information needed to determine the electronic and optical properties of the system in question.
Some authors have studied the wave optics of multilayer media using different methods [1].
Most of them focus on the case where the interfaces between adjacent layers are flat [2]-[4], meaning there are no steps in their profiles.
However, recent studies have shown that even slight deviations from perfect periodicity can lead to drastic changes in the physical behavior of the system.
For example, if the interface profile contains a single step, the corresponding energy spectrum becomes discrete [6].
In addition, the presence of steps will lead to the emergence of a new type of excited state, which is called surface plasmons. [7]

It is important to note that the impact of the presence of steps is not always negligible, as they often play a significant role in determining the overall performance of devices made from semiconductor heterostructures.

We present recent near-infrared (NIR) observations of the Javelin Cluster using the infrared array camera on the Spitzer Space Telescope, which allow us to study the population of dwarf galaxies in this rich environment for the first time at wavelengths longer than 1 micron.

We present an analytical solution that describes the dependence of soil moisture on the base saturation at the slope profile, where the base saturation is determined by groundwater level fluctuations and rainfall infiltration into the saturated zone.
The model assumes that water moves in a downhill direction, driven by gravity, through a porous medium with spatially variable hydraulic conductivity.
We demonstrate how this simple conceptualization can be used to explain the patterns of groundwater distribution observed along the slope.
Our research results indicate that the spatial variability of soil properties may play an important role in controlling hydrological processes on slopes.
Specifically, we found that topographic convergence leads to an increase in soil moisture at the bottom of the slope, as the drainage rate there is reduced.
This effect becomes more pronounced when the local gradient increases or the hydraulic conductivity decreases near the surface.
These findings are consistent with the field observations from recent slope hydrology studies conducted in the San Inés Mountains of Northern California.
Keywords: Hillslope hydrology, groundwater level

We analyzed the alignment of the galaxy spins with the tidal field in real space, using data from the Two-Mass Redshift Survey (TMRS).
We found that galaxies tend to align perpendicular to their local tidal field on scales greater than 1 Mpc/h.
This alignment is stronger in higher redshift, more massive galaxies.
The observed spin-tidal correlation can be explained by the influence of gravitational torques exerted by large-scale structures during the formation of these galaxies.
Our results indicate that this mechanism may play an important role in shaping the angular momentum of galaxies.
These findings are significant for understanding how dark matter halos acquire angular momentum and for explaining cosmic shear statistics observations.
Introduction: Galaxies form in regions of higher density in the universe, where they experience strong gravitational interactions with nearby galaxies or galaxy clusters and other objects.
During the formation process, these interactions can cause gravitational torques, affecting the direction of the angular momentum vector of the galaxy.
Conversely, the orientation of a galaxy's angular momentum determines the shape of the galaxy through the process of dynamical friction.
Therefore, some have suggested that the shape distribution of galaxies may provide information about the origin of galaxy angular momentum (e.g., Catelan and Theuns 1996; Lee et al. 2008).

However, observational studies have shown contradictory results, as there may be a preferred direction for the spin axes of galaxies in relation to the positions of nearby galaxies (see, for example, Faltenbacher et al., 2002; Bailin et al., 2005; Paz et al., 2008; and the latest research by Codis et al., 2012).

In order to understand the physical mechanisms that determine the direction of angular momentum of galaxies, we need to study the statistical properties of the rotation distribution of galaxies on a large scale in the universe.
The recent Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) allows us to accurately measure the directions of galaxies for such analysis.
For example, Lee et al. (2008) studied the alignment relationship between the galaxy spin vectors and the position angles of their nearest neighbors using the SDSS DR4 data.

We study the SLE (Schramm-Loewner Evolution) process at the interface between different phases in the two-dimensional Ising model with nearest-neighbor interactions on arbitrary planar graphs in the scale limit, and extend it to higher dimensions.

We indicate that if the underlying lattice has no loops or multiple edges, the interface is described by chordal Schramm-Löwner evolution; otherwise, it is described by radial Schramm-Löwner evolution.
The result was obtained using conformal field theory techniques.
In particular, we utilize the fact that the partition function of these models can be written as the correlation functions of the primary fields in some rational conformal field theories.

This enables us to obtain explicit formulas for the probability distribution functions of various geometric quantities related to the interface, such as their winding numbers around the vertices, among others.

Introduction  
The Schramm-Loewner evolution (SLE) process was proposed by Schramm, who demonstrated that these processes provide a natural description of the scaling limits of interfaces in statistical mechanics systems at the critical point.
These processes have been extensively studied in both theoretical and numerical aspects since then.
For example, please refer to [KSS02, SS04a, SS04b, RS05, Sch06, CS07, KS08, KSV09, KM10, MS11, MZ12, BMS13, BS14, LW15, GKS16, GM17, GK18, HJ19, HK20, JPS20].
The comprehensive review of this topic can be found in [Smi01, Sta03, Joh10].

In this work, we treat the SLE process as the two-dimensional scaling limit of different interfaces in the following model class: let G = (V, E) be any finite connected planar graph that contains no loops or multiple edges.

Consider the Ising model with nearest neighbor interactions defined on the graph \( G \). That is, let \(\{\sigma_v\}_{v \in V}\) represent a set of random variables taking values \(+1\) and \(-1\), where each \(\sigma_v\) represents the state of the vertex \(v \in V\).

The critical temperature \( T_c \) is determined by the condition \( \frac{dH}{dT} = 0 \).

We present new observations of the central region of the nearby Seyfert galaxy NGC 4258, which show that its nuclear disk is tilted by about 20 degrees relative to the plane of the stellar nucleus of the host galaxy (see Figure 1).
The distortion was detected through near-infrared integral field spectral observations obtained with the Gemini Observatory on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

We also reported the detection results of significant rotation of this distorted structure around the secondary axis, as well as evidence of reverse rotation within the innermost few hundred seconds of the core.
These results are consistent with previous studies based solely on optical data.

In addition, we found that if gas orbits around the supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy and is influenced by both gravity and magnetic fields, the kinematics of the gas in the outer disk region can be explained.
This result suggests that the observed deformation may originate from the magnetorotational instability (MRI) operating in the accretion disk around the massive black hole.

Finally, we discuss how these findings help us understand the physics of the so-called "Bardeen-Petterson effect": the alignment between the spin axis of stars and the angular momentum vector of the accreting material falling towards the central supermassive black hole.

Using the high-resolution spectra obtained with UVES on the VLT-UT2 telescope, we have determined the iron abundances of two bright blue supergiants in the Galactic globular clusters Omega Centauri and M13.
The results were compared with those obtained by other authors for similar celestial bodies in these star clusters and other globular clusters.
We found that our values are very consistent with previous measurements within their uncertainty range.
We would like to specifically confirm that the low iron content of a star discovered in Omega Centauri was previously reported by Yong et al. (2005).
This is consistent with theoretical predictions, which suggest that this cluster should primarily consist of first-generation stars formed from material enriched solely by massive supernovae.

Our analysis also indicates that the two stars studied belong to the so-called "blue straggler" group—these celestial bodies are located above the turn-off point of the main sequence in the color-magnitude diagram, yet their cores are still burning helium.

The article presents results from computer simulations of chromatin dynamics in vitro, based on a self-organizing model of nucleosome core particle (NCP) chains, with H1 histone molecules attached to them through electrostatic forces.
The NCP is modeled as a rigid cylinder with a diameter equal to the diameter of the isolated NCP observed in experiments.
Research has found that the presence of histone H1 leads to an increase in the persistence length of the chain, which is due to the formation of loops between adjacent nucleosomes.
In addition, research has shown that the presence of histone H1 leads to defects in the chain structure formed by multiple adjacent nucleosome core particles (NCPs) connected by a single H1 molecule.
These defects have a significant impact on the elastic properties of the chain.
Keywords: chromatin, self-assembly, computer simulation, elasticity, defects.
We study the evolution of an isotropic and homogeneous universe model filled with radiation and Chaplygin gas.
We found that this system has two attractors corresponding to different Hubble parameter values in the late stages.
The first corresponds to a De Sitter phase, where the energy density of Chaplygin gas dominates over other components, while the second describes a decelerating universe dominated by dark matter.
In both cases, we find that the initial conditions are determined by the value of the Hubble constant today.
Finally, we demonstrate how to use these results as initial conditions for the inflation model.

The VIMS data indicates that there is a widespread haze layer located approximately 400 to 1,000 kilometers above the surface.

We consider the non-relativistic limit of the exact solution of Einstein's field equations in vacuum, which is given by the Schwarzschild metric.
We demonstrate that this metric can serve as a special case of the general relativity Kerr-Schild hypothesis for static and axisymmetric solutions with spherical symmetry.
The corresponding line element is \( ds^2 = -(1 + \frac{2M}{r})dt^2 + (1 - \frac{2M}{r})(dr^2 + r^2 d\Omega^2) \), where \( M \) represents the mass parameter.
In order to obtain the correct Newtonian limit, we must choose the time coordinate such that dt/dτ ~ 1/Mc² asymptotically holds at spatial infinity.
This choice introduces the standard form of the Schwarzschild metric with the variable of intrinsic time \( \tau \).

We analyzed the evolution of interstellar dust particles based on the particle size distribution inferred from observations using the Infrared Space Observatory (ISO).
We have found that since the formation of the Sun, the growth of particles has primarily been dominated by coagulation processes.
During this time span, the total mass density of dust has increased by about an order of magnitude.
This increase can be explained by the addition of metal from the gas phase to pre-existing particles or by the condensation of new material from the gas phase.
In addition to these processes, we also consider the fragmentation and breakage caused by collisions between particles.
During the aggregation process, the phenomenon of fragmentation of small particles dominates, but when the particle size exceeds 0.1 microns, the fragmentation phenomenon becomes less significant.
For large particles, the breakage leads to a decrease in number density, thereby offsetting the effects of coagulation.
Our results are consistent with the findings of previous studies that used different methods.
Keyword: Interstellar Medium

The prediction of the response of structural systems affected by seismic activity is very important for the design and construction of buildings in earthquake-prone areas, especially when it involves high-rise building structures.
In this study, a neural network (ANN) model was developed using data obtained from nonlinear dynamic analysis of reinforced concrete frame structures affected by seismic soil motion records.
The ANN model consists of three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer containing 10 neurons, and an output layer that represents the maximum inter-layer drift ratio.

The input variables used include peak ground acceleration, duration, number of floors, floor height, mass density per unit floor area, damping coefficient, yield strength of the rebar, elastic modulus of the rebar, shear wall stiffness, and moment capacity of beam-column connections.
To verify the accuracy of the proposed ANN model, the results predicted by the ANN were compared with the results calculated through a nonlinear dynamic analysis program.
It can be concluded that the artificial neural network model performs well in predicting the maximum interstory drift ratio under different seismic forces.
We present multi-wavelength observations of a set of X-ray selected star-forming galaxies (SFGs) in the Chandra Deep Field-South (CDF-S).

The sample includes 16 SFGs (star-forming galaxies) with a spectral redshift between 1 and 3, which were detected through soft band (0.5-2 keV) and hard band (2-8 keV) surveys using the advanced CCD imaging spectrometer on the XMM-Newton satellite.

We used the Keck telescope to obtain spectra and measure their stellar masses and star formation rates, while using the infrared array camera on the Spitzer Space Telescope for near-infrared photometry to estimate dust extinction.
Our results indicate that these SFGs are massive systems with a mass range of M* = 10^13 - 10^14 M⊙, at z ~ 2 - 3.
They also exhibit a high specific star formation rate, ranging from 10^(-3) yr^(-1) to 10^(1) yr^(-1), indicating that intense star formation activity is underway.
We study whether anisotropy can be detected through the small-scale redshift 21 cm power spectrum (21-cm PS) of quasar H II regions during the reionization period.

In our model, quasars are assumed to be located at the peaks of dark matter density fluctuations, and they ionize the surrounding gas with an anisotropic Stroemgren sphere, the shape of which is determined by the local tidal field.

By conducting numerical simulations of different spin temperatures \( T_S \), we found that the 21 cm power spectrum exhibits a characteristic peak structure, which reflects the shape of individual H II regions.

As the temperature T S decreases, this peak structure becomes more pronounced due to the increase in the number of neutral hydrogen atoms, which is attributed to the reduction in the temperature difference between the cosmic microwave background radiation and the 21 cm emission line.
Our results suggest that this peak structure may be used to constrain the value of T S.
However, since there are many other factors affecting the 21 cm PS besides T S, further research is needed before drawing any conclusions about its detectability.

We consider the problem of time evolution of quantum fields in the Milne universe, which is an open Friedmann-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker universe with negative spatial curvature and a vanishing cosmological constant.
We have proven that there is no normalizable solution to the Klein-Gordon equation corresponding to macroscopic particles at early times (as \( t \to -\infty \)).
This result can be understood as follows.
The Milne universe has a singularity at t = 0, where all physical quantities tend towards infinity.
Specifically, the energy density diverges near this point like \(1/t^2\).
Therefore, any particle state concentrated around \( t=0 \) will have infinite energy.
Therefore, it cannot correspond to a physically meaningful solution of the field equations.
On the other hand, we find that there are normalizable states that describe early massless particles.
These states represent the past states of gravitons or photons propagating along geodesics towards the singularity of the Big Bang.
A review of the topological classification of clusters was conducted, emphasizing the roles of symmetry and topology in determining cluster structure.

The concept of "topology" refers to the connectivity between atoms or molecules within a cluster; it can be used as an organizational principle to classify clusters into different families based on structural similarity.
This review mainly focuses on metal clusters (i.e., clusters containing one or more metal elements), but also discusses some examples of recently studied non-metal clusters.
In addition, we briefly discussed how this method can be applied to classify the clusters formed in chemical reactions.
Finally, we propose some open questions related to cluster topology.
Topology plays an important role in understanding the structure of matter, encompassing all scales from atomic nuclei to macroscopic materials such as crystals.
It provides a useful framework for classifying clusters based on structural similarity.
Here, we briefly outline the recent progress made in developing classification schemes for collective systems by utilizing concepts borrowed from condensed matter physics.
We studied the phase diagram and critical behavior of an anisotropic system composed of Nx × Ny spins, which are described by the two-dimensional XY model on a square lattice.

We found that, based on the value of J1 / J2 (J2 > 0), it can be divided into three stages: when J1 / J2 is small, it is in a ferromagnetic state; when J1 / J2 is in an intermediate value, it is in a helical state; and when J1 / J2 is large, it is in a paramagnetic state.
The transitions of these states belong to the universality class of the Ising model.
We particularly point out that the spiral state has a non-trivial structure, which can be regarded as a superposition of ferromagnetically ordered regions in different directions.
This result indicates that the helical state may be somewhat correlated with the physical properties of high-temperature superconductors.

On the other hand, when the exchange interactions along the two directions do not disappear simultaneously, the ground state is always antiferromagnetic.

The Fermi Large Area Telescope (LAT) has revolutionized our understanding of broadband radio sources (blazars) by providing unprecedented sensitivity to gamma rays above 100 MeV.
The LAT is now routinely detecting flaring activities at GeV energies, which were not observed by previous instruments such as EGRET on CGRO or AGILE/GRID.
This new set of data allows us to explore the physical properties of these objects in greater depth than ever before.
In this speech, I will discuss how we can utilize the upcoming generation of space observatories, including GLAST and EXIST, to study blazars across a broader energy range.
These tasks promise to provide detailed information about the physical processes occurring inside relativistic jets through observations across multiple photon energy bands.

We report an experiment that tests the predictions of quantum mechanics and local hidden variable theories in Bell states with two entangled photons, using polarization entanglement swapping to create a loophole-free violation of Bell inequalities.

The experiment was conducted using polarization-entangled photon pairs generated through spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC) in a nonlinear crystal, pumped by a continuous wave laser at 405 nanometers.
The half-wave plate rotated the polarization of one of the photons by 45 degrees, until it entered a beam splitter, which separated the pair of photons into two spatially separated beams.

One beam of light passes through a quarter-wave plate, with the fast axis of the plate forming an angle of 22.5 degrees with the horizontal plane; this converts the horizontal polarized component of the electric field vector of the beam into vertical polarized light.
After passing through another quarter-wave plate, and with its fast axis still aligned with the vertical direction, the two components are converted back into horizontally polarized light.
This transformation can be expressed as: H → V → H = HVH.

Another beam directly reaches Alice's measurement station, where she measures along three different axes corresponding to the projections of the ground state |V>, |H>, and |D>, where D represents the diagonal.
Bob measures his photons along four different axes, and these axes correspond to the projections.

We study how classical and quantum uncertainty affect price dynamics in an incomplete information environment, where information agents can access different sources of information about the underlying state variables.

We indicate that when traders do not have common knowledge of the true value of state variables, even if everyone is rational and risk-neutral, they may have differing expectations about its future evolution.
This divergence leads to price fluctuations, which may be magnified by the presence of noise traders who trade solely based on their private signals.
In this case, we find that stock returns exhibit volatility clustering and fat-tailed phenomena, which is similar to what has been empirically observed.
Finally, we prove that these effects persist for classical and quantum states with non-Gaussian statistics.
The results presented here provide new insights into the role of uncertainty in shaping the statistical properties of asset returns.
They also suggested potential avenues for further research aimed at understanding the origins of such phenomena in more realistic trading behavior models.
We present the results of our study on the bimodality of galaxies and active galactic nuclei (AGN).

We found that there is no significant difference in the proportion of active galactic nuclei (AGN) in red and blue host galaxies, but we did observe that there is an excess of active galactic nuclei in intermediate-color galaxies compared to normal galaxies.

This indicates that active galactic nuclei (AGNs) do not preferentially occur in red or blue galaxies, as was previously thought; rather, they seem to be more common in galaxies with intermediate colors.
The lack of correlation between the color of galaxies and the activity of active galactic nuclei (AGN) may indicate that AGN play only a minor role in suppressing star formation in massive galaxies.
Additionally, this may indicate that active galactic nuclei (AGNs) have different effects based on their luminosity and/or accretion rate.
In addition, we found that most active galactic nuclei (AGNs) are located in galaxies with nuclear bulges, regardless of whether these galaxies are classified as early-type or late-type systems.

We analyzed the final masses of the gas giants in our solar system based on their orbital parameters and the compositions inferred from remote sensing observations.
We found that if Jupiter forms at a distance of 5 AU or closer, its mass and composition are consistent; while Saturn's mass can only be explained if it formed beyond 10 AU.
The formation of Uranus requires additional processes, such as ice condensation, to explain its high density.
Neptune may have initially been larger than we see today, but it lost most of its initial mass due to intense stellar radiation and underwent photodissociation.
Our research results indicate that the core accumulation model of planet formation cannot fully explain all the observed characteristics of gas giant planets.

We studied the quantum Hall effect (QHE) in monolayer graphene and its interaction with magnetism by using an effective low-energy model that takes into account the interactions between electrons and disorder effects.
We demonstrate how to derive this model from fundamental principles and discuss some of its main characteristics.
Specifically, we found that at half-filling, it exhibits two distinct phases depending on the strength of the Coulomb interaction between the electrons.

For weak coupling, these phase transitions induced by spontaneous breaking of time-reversal symmetry become decoupled; for strong coupling, they correspond respectively to the conventional quantum Hall effect state and a novel fractional topological insulator characterized by rotating edge states.
The latter has been shown to be equivalent to a spin-1/2 Heisenberg antiferromagnet on a honeycomb lattice, and can thus be described within the framework of the so-called SU(4) boson representation.
We report the discovery of an extremely bright and hot (surface temperature T_eff = 300,000 K) blue supergiant in the star cluster NGC 6231, with a mass loss rate of 10^-6 M_sun/year.
The object is 1 kiloparsec away from Earth, with a brightness of 5 x 10^{5} solar luminosities.
It shows strong emission lines from He II 4686 Å, N III 4641 Å, C IV 5801 Å, O V 7322 Å, and the Balmer series of H.
We suggest that this celestial body may be a member of the Cygnus OB2 cluster, which contains several other high-quality stars.
This will make it one of the brightest single stars known outside the Milky Way.
If this object is confirmed through further observations, it will provide important constraints for the interstellar evolution model of massive stars.
Keywords: Open Cluster; Blue Supergiant Star

We consider a problem of finding approximate solutions in convex optimization problems with non-convex objective functions and linear constraints, where the feasible region is defined by a set of equality or inequality constraints.

We indicate that, under certain conditions, this problem can be effectively solved by combining gradient descent methods, which are used to solve subproblems in each iteration, with a line search method based on the Armijo-Goldstein condition.
The proposed algorithm has been implemented as part of the open-source software package CVXPY (http://cvxpy.org/).
We present numerical experiments that demonstrate the effectiveness of our method.
Keywords: convex optimization, non-convex objective function, saddle point problem, gradient descent method, line search algorithm, Amihud-Goldstein condition.

We have provided integral field spectroscopy observations of three radio galaxies located at high redshift (z ~ 2.5) that are known to be surrounded by extended Lyman-alpha halos.
The main objective is to study their kinematics and physical conditions in order to understand how these celestial bodies evolved into massive elliptical galaxies at low redshift.
We found that all three sources exhibit complex velocity fields, characterized by rotation predominantly around an axis perpendicular to the radio jet.
In addition, we detected several components that show a blue shift velocity relative to the systemic redshift of up to -500 kilometers per second.
These features may represent outflows driven by active galactic nucleus feedback or galaxy winds triggered by star formation activity.
Finally, we use the [OII] emission line to measure the gas density distribution and estimate the mass of ionized hydrogen around each galaxy.
Our results indicate that the observed Lyα halos have a mass range between 10^10 M_sol and 10^11 M_sol.

We report two new brown dwarf candidates discovered through direct imaging with NACO/VLT, which are located approximately 100 AU from their host stars and belong to the open star clusters NGC 2423 (M67) and NGC 4349.
The first celestial body is located near the center of the star cluster, with an estimated mass between 0.03 and 0.07 M.
This was found to be part of our survey of low-mass companions to nearby young solar-type stars.
We also used adaptive optics technology to conduct follow-up observations of this candidate object, thereby confirming its substellar characteristics.
The second object is located near the core radius of the star cluster, with an estimated mass of less than 0.01 M.

The companion object could be a planetary companion or a very low-mass stellar companion, depending on whether it formed through gravitational instability or was formed by fragmentation during cloud collapse.
The masses of these two celestial bodies far exceed the planet formation models predicted by current disk accretion theories.

We reported observations using the satellite "Suzaku" to study the X-ray variability of the active galactic nucleus (AGN) NGC 3783, which is considered one of the brightest Seyfert 1 galaxies and stands out particularly in the soft X-ray band.
We found that the flux of the iron Kα line and the continuous spectrum changed by about twice over a period of 100 kiloseconds.
The phase delay between the two components is estimated to be approximately 0.1 seconds through cross-correlation analysis.
This result indicates that there is some physical connection between them.
In addition, we detected a significant time delay in the higher-order harmonics of the fundamental frequency component (up to the third harmonic).
These results indicate that the observed variability may be due to the echo effect caused by the variable illumination of the accretion disk around the supermassive black hole.
Keywords: Reverb; Time delay; Wire; Active galactic nucleus (AGN)

We propose a method for calculating the effective material properties of thin-layer structures, which are composed of two or more different materials and their periodic microstructures.

Classical novae have been known since ancient times, but the physical mechanisms behind them are still poorly understood.
They are thought to be caused by runaway thermonuclear reactions triggered by unstable nuclear burning on the surface of white dwarfs in close binary systems.
However, there are still many unresolved questions regarding how this process takes place and what happens afterwards.
One such question involves the nature of the magnetic field of white dwarfs.
It is generally believed that the magnetic field of a white dwarf plays a key role in determining whether a system will undergo runaway thermonuclear reactions.

If the magnetic field of a white dwarf is too weak, it will not go out of control; if the magnetic field is strong enough, then the white dwarf can become fully convective, leading to stable hydrogen burning, which in turn prevents further explosive activity.

The complexity of this image lies in the fact that, although the magnetic fields of certain white dwarfs are considered too weak to prevent them from fully convecting, they still exhibit periodic eruptions.

Such objects are referred to as intermediate polars (IPs). In this case, the magnetic field of the white dwarf is strong enough to synchronize the rotational periods of the two stars, but it does not interfere with the process of material flowing towards the white dwarf.

We conducted a detailed study on how to correct the effects of various observational biases on the determination of the white dwarf luminosity function (WDLF).
We found that WDLF is influenced by multiple factors, such as photometric calibration errors, incompleteness due to detection limitations, and contamination from unresolved binary stars.
In order to obtain an unbiased estimate of the true WDLF, we need to properly account for these influences.

We provided an explicit expression for the irreducible form of the interaction terms of the sixth-order gravity with respect to the variation of the metric, which is valid at all orders of perturbation theory.

In recent years, higher-order derivative gravity theories have garnered new attention, primarily due to their potential role in quantum gravity phenomenology (see, for example), but also because they provide interesting alternatives to standard General Relativity (GR) in modified gravity scenarios.

One of the main obstacles is that the equations of motion derived from these action quantities contain arbitrary higher-order derivatives, which makes them difficult or impossible to solve analytically.
One method to solve this problem is to expand the field around some fixed background solution and truncate the resulting series expansion after a finite number of terms.

Although this method can obtain useful information about the dynamics of the considered system, it fails to capture important features such as the feedback effects between different modes of the same field or the interactions between different fields.

For example, in the case of inflationary cosmology based on higher derivative gravity, the truncated perturbative expansion does not accurately reproduce the observed level of primordial non-Gaussianity.
A more systematic approach to addressing these issues is to use the covariant technique originally developed within the framework of general relativity.

The purpose of this paper is to provide an overview of the application of the state-of-the-art Hartree-Fock self-consistent field (SCF) methods in solving quantum chemistry problems, with a particular emphasis on their numerical aspects.
Chapter One introduces the basic concepts related to molecular orbital theory and the use of density functional theory (DFT) for electronic structure calculations.
In particular, we discussed how to utilize density functional theory (DFT) through Kohn-Sham orbitals to study the ground state properties of molecules.
We also present some basic results regarding the convergence of iterative schemes commonly used in the self-consistent field method.

Chapter two involves a description of several types of algorithms based on direct minimization techniques, which have been developed over the past few decades for numerically solving the Hartree-Fock equations.
These methods include the Roothaan-Hall method, the Davidson algorithm and its variants, such as the Pulay-Davidson scheme or the linearized Davidson method.

We analyzed the transition between the first-generation stars and the second-generation stars. The second-generation stars were formed from the gravitational collapse of primordial gas clouds within a mass range of \(10^4 M_{\odot}\) to \(10^6 M_{\odot}\).

We propose an algorithm to compute a symbolic model that approximates the original continuous-time system in a bisimulation manner, which can be used for abstraction in model checking and controller synthesis problems.
The proposed method is based on using numerical methods such as finite difference methods or spectral collocation techniques to compute approximate solutions to the Hamilton-Jacobi equation.
We demonstrate how this method can be applied to several types of nonlinear control systems, including switched affine systems, piecewise affine systems, and hybrid automata.
Finally, we illustrate our results by applying them to two examples.
Keywords: Approximate double simulation, symbolic model checking, nonlinear control systems, finite difference method, spectral collocation technique.

The stability, equilibrium state, and dynamic behavior of coronal loops of the Sun were studied, and an analysis was conducted on an idealized model loop system with a constant cross-section using the principle of thermodynamic irreversible energy.
The control equation for this problem is derived from the total pressure disturbance within the loop and the variation of cross-sectional area along the length of the loop.
This indicates that these two variables can represent each other through the nonlinear differential equations that describe the evolution of the loop system.
This equation was solved numerically under different initial conditions to correspond to various physical situations.
Specifically, it was found that the circuit may expand or contract, depending on whether the initial value of the total pressure disturbance is positive or negative.

In addition, the results indicate that if the initial values of the total pressure disturbance and cross-sectional area change meet certain constraints, there exists only one stable equilibrium state at any given moment.
Finally, when the initial conditions correspond to a static equilibrium solution, the time evolution of the loop system is studied.

We propose an explanation for the phenomenon of excess gamma-ray radiation observed by the Energetic Gamma Ray Experiment Telescope (EGRET) at energies exceeding 10 GeV, which is referred to as the "GeV anomaly."
We show that if there exist two populations of pulsars with different magnetic field strengths, this excess phenomenon can be explained.
The first type of interstellar population consists of young pulsars, whose magnetic fields decay rapidly due to the slowdown from fast rotation.
These pulsars produced most of the high-energy photons detected by EGRET.
The second type of pulsars is composed of older pulsars, which have slower average rotation speeds compared to younger pulsars, and as a result, their magnetic fields decay more slowly.
The high-energy radiation produced by the second type of pulsars is less, but it makes a significant contribution to the total number of pulsars.
Our model predicts that the Fermi satellite should be able to detect many new pulsar candidates that have not been seen before.
In addition, we expect that some newly discovered pulsars will exhibit very high luminosity compared to other pulsars.
We studied how the evolution of the Carter constant in a binary system with a rotating black hole depends on the spin and mass ratio, using numerical relativity simulations.
We found that when the spins are in an aligned or anti-aligned state, the dependence is weaker, while when the angle between them is in an intermediate state, the dependence is stronger.
The results indicate that it may be possible to measure the quadrupole moment of a black hole by observing the gravitational waves emitted during the late stages of accretion.
This will provide information about the spacetime geometry near the event horizon, which cannot be obtained through other means.

In this work, we investigate how the evolution of the so-called Carter constant depends on the spin and mass ratio of the two rotating black holes in a binary system.
The Carter constant is one of several motion constants related to the geodesic orbits around a Kerr black hole (Carter, 1968).

It is used to probe the spacetime geometry near the event horizon, as its value will only vary significantly over time when there is significant non-spherical symmetry at small radii (Bardeen 1973; Thorne et al. 1986).
For example, the presence of a massive accretion disk will lead to a change in the Carter constant, even if the total angular momentum of the system remains constant (Kerr 1963).

Previous studies have shown that the orbital evolution of non-rotating binary stars is influenced by the black hole quadrupole moment \( Q = \frac{M(1 - S^2)}{c^2R^2} \), where \( S \) represents the dimensionless spin parameter of each black hole (Damour & Nagar 1999).
"However, once the black hole enters the final plunging phase, the effects will become negligible due to the rapid orbital decay caused by the emission of gravitational waves."
On the other hand, recent observations have shown that many galactic nuclei contain supermassive black holes, with masses of up to 10^9 solar masses (for example, Gebhardt et al. (2000)).
These objects are expected to reach their final merger state after undergoing multiple mass transfer phases.
In this evolutionary process, black holes can acquire a large amount of angular momentum and/or through tidal interactions.

We use the semiclassical theory of diffusive conductors with spin-orbit scattering to study the nonequilibrium spin-dependent transport characteristics of conventional metal-superconductor (NS) and ferromagnet-superconductor (FS) hybrid systems.

We demonstrate that, due to the pairing correlation caused by proximity effects between the electrons on both sides of the NS interface, there is an additional contribution to the current density, which depends on the relative orientation of magnetization in the F layer and the S layer.
This leads to the emergence of an anomalous Josephson-like current phase relation in the FS junction.

Additionally, we found that if the angle between the magnetization directions of the N region and the S region becomes sufficiently large, the Andreev reflection at the NS interface can be significantly suppressed.
The suppression of Andreev reflection leads to a reduction in the conductivity of the NS junction compared to its value in the equilibrium state.
Finally, we discussed the possible experimental realizations of our predictions.

The cosmological constant is one of the most important parameters in modern physics, and its value has been determined through observation to be very small but not zero.
In this article, we will discuss how to interpret it as quantum gravitational effects at very high energies.

We will also show that if the universe experienced a period of accelerated expansion after the Big Bang, there should be primordial gravitational waves, which may have observable effects on the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMBR).

Finally, we will argue that these effects may provide us with new ways to test the differences between the predictions of general relativity and those of other theories, such as string theory or loop quantum gravity.
The cosmological constant is one of the most important parameters in modern physics.
Its value is determined through observation to be extremely small but non-zero.

It plays a crucial role in our understanding of the evolution of the universe, as it determines whether the current accelerated expansion of spacetime will continue indefinitely or will eventually slow down and stop.
This problem remains unresolved after years of research on the nature of dark energy.

We provide newly acquired optical photometric data for the open star cluster NGC 6791, obtained using the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) on the Hubble Space Telescope as part of project GO-12775 (Principal Investigator: A. Dotter).

The data covers a 0.5 square degree area centered on the star cluster's center, with high spatial resolution (0.1 arc seconds per pixel), allowing us to study individual stars with brightness up to magnitude 20.

We conducted observations by combining the archived WFC3/UVIS images obtained from project GO-10775 (Principal Investigator: J. Kalirai) and GO-11775 (Principal Investigator: S. Casagrande) to derive accurate stellar parameters for over 1,000 red giant branch (RGB) stars in the star cluster.
Our analysis indicates that RGB mass loss is very efficient in low-mass stars, leading to the formation of white dwarfs with masses below 0.45 M.
This result has significant implications for our understanding of the evolution of low-mass stars at the end of their life cycles.
Keywords: Open Cluster

We present the results of gravitational wave radiation in the final stage of black hole binary mergers, during which an accretion disk forms around the black holes, and their orbital evolution is driven by radiation reaction.
We use numerical relativity simulations to study how the mass loss rate due to gravitational waves depends on the magnitudes and directions of the spins of the two black holes.

Our main result is that for equal-mass binary stars with spin alignment (where the spins are aligned or anti-aligned with the orbital angular momentum), the total radiated energy monotonically increases as the system loses orbital energy through gravitational waves.
For cases with unequal mass and/or misaligned rotation, we find that the launch power may exhibit significant fluctuations on time scales comparable to the orbital period.
The reason for these fluctuations is that the amount of gravitational wave luminosity generated at each moment strongly depends on whether the orbit of the black hole has become circularized.
The resulting variability may have significant implications for observing merging galaxies using gravitational wave detectors like LIGO/VIRGO.

The National Science Foundation (NSF) recently established an "Exoplanet Working Group" aimed at identifying key scientific objectives for future space missions in exoplanet research, including radio astronomical measurements.
In this white paper, we present how to design such tasks to achieve the vision of these goals.
We believe that a dedicated radio telescope is needed to discover and characterize exoplanets by detecting their radio emissions.

The proposed instrument will have unprecedented sensitivity in the decimeter wavelength range, allowing it to detect planet-mass companions around nearby stars and directly measure the mass of known giant planet systems.
This will enable us to address fundamental questions about the formation and evolution of planetary systems.
Keywords: radio astronomy, exoplanet detection, characterization of planetary systems, space mission concept development.

We investigated the phase diagram and electronic structure of the bilayer ruthenate Sr3Ru2O7 using density functional theory (DFT). The results show that this material is close to an insulator-metal phase transition driven by interlayer charge transfer.
We found that the topology of the Fermi surface undergoes significant changes at the metal-insulator boundary, with new hole pockets appearing at the center of the Brillouin zone.
The calculated band gap is in excellent agreement with the experimental results of the single crystal.
In addition, we predict the existence of two competing vortex phases near the metal-insulator boundary.
One material has in-plane anisotropy along the Ru-O-Ru bond direction, while another material has out-of-plane anisotropy perpendicular to that direction.
These results provide insights into the source of structural distortions observed in the bilayer ruthenium compounds.
The double-layer ruthenate has recently attracted considerable attention due to its rich physical properties, including unconventional superconductivity and quantum critical behavior.

The second law of thermodynamics is one of the most important laws in physics, indicating that in a closed system, entropy always increases over time.
In this work, we present an experimental proof of the second law based on volume entropy and mechanical energy dissipation.
We demonstrated how to measure volumetric entropy using two different methods (a direct method and an indirect method), and then we compared these results with theoretical predictions.
The experiment was conducted at room temperature and atmospheric pressure.
Our results confirm that the volumetric entropy always increases over time, which is consistent with theoretical predictions.
This result also confirms that our measurement system is functioning properly.
Finally, we discussed some possible applications of our method.

However, none of them could provide complete evidence because they did not take into account all relevant physical quantities.

We conducted near-infrared (NIR) spectral and photometric observations of the young open star cluster IRAS 18511+0146; we found that it is likely a medium-mass star formation region with a total luminosity of approximately ~10^6 L_Sun.

We identified two different populations within this star cluster; one population has spectral types ranging from F0 to F5V, while the other population exhibits emission line features indicating the presence of an accretion disk around a pre-main-sequence star.
The latter group seems to be less than 10 million years old based on their position in the Herotuo.
This indicates that these celestial bodies are very young objects, possibly still embedded in the molecular clouds where they were born.

Through N-body simulations, we demonstrate that if these star clusters can withstand the destructive tidal forces during their formation, they can evolve into open clusters similar to those observed today.
In addition, we also estimate the age distribution among the sample members through the equivalent width of the Pα line and the strength of the Brackett gamma line.
We provide new infrared (IR) luminosity measurements obtained for the galaxy cluster MS1054-03 at redshift z = 0.83, which were acquired using the ISOCAM instrument on the ISO satellite.
These data are used to study the star formation activity in the rich environment of this star cluster.
We find that the infrared luminosity function is well fitted by the Schechter function, with L* ~ 1 x 10^12 L⊙ and α ~ -1.7, applicable in the range of 8 to 1000 microns.
This result suggests that there may be an excess of faint galaxies compared to local galaxy clusters.
In addition, we detected several bright sources that were identified as candidates for active galactic nuclei based on their mid-infrared colors.
These objects appear to be preferentially located at the center of the star cluster, suggesting that they may have been triggered by interactions or mergers between galaxies.
Finally, we combine our results with published optical spectroscopy to study how the properties of individual galaxies evolve over time.
The fine structure of solar prominences has been studied using data obtained from the Swedish 1-meter Solar Telescope (SST).
The observation was conducted in the Hα and Ca II 8542 Å lines, which indicates that the shape of the fine structure varies depending on its position relative to the magnetic field.

In addition, we found that there are two types of fine structures; one type exhibits an elongated shape in the direction parallel to the local magnetic field, while the other type presents a circular shape in the direction perpendicular to the local magnetic field.
We also found that some fine structures appeared to be intertwined.
The results indicate that the fine structures may be formed by plasma flows driven by magnetic reconnection between adjacent magnetic flux tubes.
Keywords: solar prominence, fine structure, magnetic field, plasma flow, reconnection.

We propose an analytical model to describe the evolution of 21 cm brightness temperature fluctuations during the cosmic reionization period, which is based on correlated random walks (CRWs).

We demonstrated that the CRW model can reproduce many of the heavy ionization features observed in numerical simulations, including the power spectrum on large scales and the characteristic shapes of cross-correlations between different redshifts.

GRI (Gamma Ray Imager) is a proposed astrophysical space observatory for the French Space Agency CNES and NASA, aimed at studying gamma-ray bursts, active galactic nuclei, and other high-energy astronomical phenomena.
It will be launched by a Soviet Soyuz rocket and equipped with a Fregat upper stage, sending it to a solar orbit at the Sun-Earth L2 point, which is 1 AU away from Earth.

The main instruments consist of two coded mask telescopes, capable of simultaneously observing in the energy range from 20 MeV to 300 GeV. Each telescope has a large field of view covering 2 steradians and a spatial resolution better than 0.1 degrees.
The third detector module provides additional information about the background radiation environment for each telescope.
This article describes the design concept of the innovative instrument.

We analyzed the connections between different types of galaxies, with data sourced from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).

We used two methods to classify galaxies into four categories: star-forming galaxies (SFG), active galactic nucleus host galaxies (AGNHG), early-type galaxies with emission lines (ETGEL), and early-type galaxies without emission lines (ETGSIL).
The first method is based on Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and is applied to the spectral data of all galaxies classified as spectral targets by the SDSS pipeline.
The second method applies principal component analysis (PCA) only to a subset of galaxies that are morphologically selected to have bulges dominated by ancient star clusters.
In these two cases, we find that ETGs form a continuous sequence in their spectral characteristics, with SFGs evolving into ETGSILs through ETGELs.

This evolutionary pathway can be described by a simple linear combination that combines three characteristic vectors corresponding to the most prominent features in the average spectra of each type of galaxy.

We present observations from the Spitzer Space Telescope of 12 members of the Taurus star-forming region, located nearby (at a distance of 140 parsecs), at wavelengths of 24, 70, and 160 micrometers, with ages ranging from 1 million to 10 million years.
We found that all sources exhibit excessive radiation beyond the level of the photosphere, indicating the presence of circumstellar material around each star.
Most of these objects are surrounded by optically thick disks, which can be well fitted using a single-temperature blackbody model.
However, we also identified three systems where the disk may have inner holes or gaps: TW Hya, DM Tau, and GM Aur.
In addition, we discovered two transitional disks around V4046 Sgr and Sz 91.
These results indicate that most stars in our sample retain their original disks for at least 5 million years after formation.

We studied the decoherence of macroscopic quantum superpositions in open systems and showed that it is possible to prepare such states with high fidelity using current experimental techniques.
We consider two different types of macroscopic superposition: coherent spin states (CSS) and Schrödinger cat states (SCS).
For CSS, we found that the decay rate is proportional to \(1/N\), where \(N\) is the number of particles involved in that state.
This scaling law can be understood by considering the individual effects of spontaneous emission on each particle.
In contrast, for SCS, the scaling of the decay rate is proportional to \(1/\sqrt{N}\), which cannot be explained by treating individual particles independently.
On the contrary, we discuss whether this behavior is caused by the collective effects among all particles in the system.
Finally, we discuss how to experimentally validate these results.
The decoherence of macroscopic superpositions has been widely studied in recent years [1-3].
It has been theoretically shown [4] and experimentally confirmed [5, 6] that macroscopic superposition states are extremely fragile to environmental noise.

The Gemini Deep Planet Survey (GDPS) is an ongoing research project aimed at surveying transiting planets around bright stars using the twin 8-meter telescopes of the Gemini Observatory located in Hawaii and Chile.

GDPS uses two different techniques to search for exoplanets. One method is to look for periodic dimming events caused by planets passing in front of their host stars. Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are intense gamma-ray flashes that last only a few milliseconds. They were discovered over thirty years ago, but their exact causes remain unknown.

One of the most confusing aspects of this phenomenon is the remarkable diversity of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) themselves; while some bursts exhibit smooth power-law spectra extending up to hundreds of kiloelectronvolts, others display complex characteristics, including multiple peaks and/or breaks in the energy distribution.

Despite this diversity, many studies have found that all gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) share some common characteristics, which can be summarized into two main empirical relations known as the Amati relation and the Ghirlanda relation.
These two relationships associate the peak photon flux at high energies (>100 MeV) with other observable quantities, such as the total flux emitted during the burst and its duration.

Although both relationships seem to hold statistically when applied to large sample outbreaks, they do not necessarily reflect the intrinsic connections between the various observable quantities involved.

Indeed, recent observational activities have shown that if attempts are made to apply these relationships to individual outbreaks rather than to the entire population, the dispersion around each relationship will significantly increase.

We present the results of calculations on the formation of dust in supernova ejecta using a one-dimensional radiative hydrodynamics code combined with a chemical network. This includes mechanisms that promote particle growth through deposition on existing particles and aggregation between particles.
We found that if there is enough carbon available to produce amorphous carbon particles, dust can form effectively at temperatures below 1000 K.

We studied the twisting oscillations of inhomogeneous magnetic flux tubes with longitudinal density variations and uniform twisting embedded in a gravitationally stratified atmosphere.
The governing equations are derived by using the thin-tube approximation for both the equilibrium state and linear perturbations.

In each mode, we calculate the frequency and the damping time caused by radiation losses.
The results indicate that the frequency of these modes depends on the density contrast between the bottom and the top of the annular channel.

Entropy is a measure of uncertainty, while the entropy power inequality (EPI) quantifies the trade-off between information transmission rates in different communication channels.

Introduction  
The discovery of exoplanetary giants has been a significant achievement in modern astronomy over the past decade.
However, only about 10% of the known planetary systems contain such large bodies.
Most of these were discovered using high-precision Doppler spectroscopy or direct imaging methods.
In comparison, very few low-quality companions have been discovered so far, as they produce smaller reflective motions and/or have luminosities lower than those of higher-mass companions.
Therefore, there is a significant range in the mass distribution of known exoplanets, varying from a few times the mass of Earth to masses similar to that of Neptune.
Therefore, finding low-quality companions is very important, as they can provide valuable information about the planet formation process.
One possible method to detect low-quality companions is to use space telescopes like the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) for high angular resolution observations.
Such observations allow us to measure the position angle of the host star relative to its nearby neighboring stars.

If we assume that the observed motion is solely due to the gravitational interaction with another celestial body, then we can derive the projected separation distance and position angle of the companion star.
By combining these results with simultaneous accurate radial velocity measurements, we can obtain the complete three-dimensional orbit of the companion star, allowing us to calculate its mass.

We present for the first time results from a three-dimensional atmospheric circulation model, which incorporates radiative transfer and realistic optical thickness, to study the atmospheric dynamics of short-period exoplanetary gas giants (EGPs).
We found that the nighttime temperature largely depends on opacity, which determines how much energy can be radiated into space.
As we reduce opacity, the day-night contrast increases because the heat lost in the atmosphere on the night side decreases.
This effect is more pronounced at lower pressures, at which point the convection becomes ineffective.
At sufficiently low opacity, the planet cools completely in its orbit, resulting in an exceptionally cold night side.
Our simulation shows that external gas planets (EGPs) may have very different climates due to their varying compositions.

We propose an analytical theory to describe the capillary forces between two contacting spherical particles submerged in a liquid, which remains valid even when the separation distance between the particles is comparable to their size.

We conducted an experimental study on the complementarity between the measurement of the position information and momentum information of single photons, using an improved version of the original Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen photon box experiment.
The results show that there is no violation of Bell's inequalities or any other form of non-locality for this specific measurement scheme.
We also demonstrated how our experimental setup can be used to study quantum contextuality by conducting two different experiments under the same conditions, but with opposite results.
In one case, we observed a violation of Bell's inequality, while in another case, there was no violation.
This indicates that the observed behavior cannot be explained by classical physics and demonstrates quantum contextuality.
Quantum mechanics predicts that certain physical quantities, such as position and momentum, cannot have definite values simultaneously.
These quantities only exist in the probability distribution that evolves over time according to the Schrödinger equation.

However, studies have shown that if both position and momentum are measured simultaneously, their respective probabilities will interfere, resulting in a probability of zero for measuring either quantity at its most probable value [1].
This phenomenon is known as the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, which leads to the concept of complementarity: it is impossible to simultaneously observe all properties of a system.

We proposed an analytical model to calculate the aperture efficiency of a reflecting antenna with circularly polarized feed, which is based on ray tracing conducted through the feed waveguide's optics and the physical optics (PO) of the aperture plane.
The PO method is used to calculate the electric field distribution on the aperture surface by solving Maxwell's equations using Green's functions.
We have demonstrated that this method can be applied to any type of feedhorn, including corrugated conical horns or dual-polarized logarithmic periodic dipole arrays.

This work is inspired by our recent study on the aperture efficiency of two types of antennas operating at 1.4 GHz: one is a single-dish radio telescope equipped with a corrugated conical feed horn, and the other is an array interferometer composed of eight log-periodic dipole array elements.
In both cases, we found that the numerical results obtained from our new model are in good agreement with the experimental data.

The game is a mathematical model used to describe situations in which multiple decision-makers interact strategically.

We study the randomly interlaced empty set in \( \mathbb{R}^d \) (where \( d > 1 \)), which is defined as the complement of the union of all open paths that start from 0 and reach time 1.
We prove that its Hausdorff dimension is almost surely equal to \(d-1\) by showing that its upper Minkowski dimension is equal to this value with probability 1.

This result extends the previous findings of Lawler, Schramm, and Werner (in "Probability Surveys," 24(3), 1997) as well as Benjamini, Kalai, and Schramm (in "Journal of Functional Analysis," 157(1), 2000) regarding the empty set of simple random walks.
The proof heavily relies on the latest developments in the geometry of Brownian motion and the theory of stable processes.
We use the estimates of the Green's function for killed Brownian motion from Bass and Burdzy (Annals of the Henry Poincaré Institute, 22(2), 1999).
The main motivation for our work comes from percolation theory, in which the random walk of empty sets plays a crucial role.
Indeed, we have demonstrated how our technology can be used to obtain new information about the critical behavior of the key percolation model on Zd.

The Standard Model (SM) is a very successful theory, but it still leaves many unanswered questions in the realm of high-energy physics.

Especially, there are currently no known fundamental principles to explain why there are such large mass differences among the three generations of quarks and leptons in the Standard Model, or how gravity fits into this picture.
Theories beyond the standard model attempt to address these issues by introducing new particles and/or interactions that may be observed in future experiments.
Supersymmetry (SUSY), as an example, introduces partners for all Standard Model (SM) fields that differ in spin by half a unit.
The quantum numbers of these partner states are the same as their counterparts in the Standard Model, thus if supersymmetry is broken at low energy scales, they can mix with Standard Model particles.
This mixture may lead to deviations in observable quantities (such as cross-sections and decay rates) from the predictions of the standard model.
Many extensions of the Standard Model also predict new phenomena related to additional spacetime dimensions.
For example, theories based on string theory/M-theory often include extra spatial dimensions that are compactified to tiny sizes.

If these extra dimensions exist, we should observe evidence of their effects through virtual exchanges of Kaluza-Klein excited states of gravitons and other particles among the standard model fields localized on our four-dimensional world volume.
The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is expected to produce new particles that could become candidates for dark matter, such as supersymmetric partners of quarks or leptons.
In this speech, I will discuss how to use the data collected by the ATLAS experiment during Run 1 of the LHC to search for these features.
The results are presented in the form of production cross-sectional constraints and mass exclusion zones.
Ultimately, the prospects of using Run 2 data for future searches were discussed.

The rapid development of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) has led to an increasing demand for wireless communication, which is expected to be met through the use of Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA).

In this article, we propose a novel CDMA-based Intelligent Transportation System (ITS) that, compared to existing technologies such as Global Positioning System (GPS), Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN), Bluetooth, or ZigBee, will provide higher data transmission rates and lower latency services, along with improved security features.
The proposed system consists of three main components: the roadside unit (RSU), mobile vehicles equipped with onboard units (OBU), and the central server located at the traffic control center (TCC).
We will first introduce the basic concepts of the proposed system, and then describe its key features.
Then, we discussed some important issues related to the proposed system design, including channel modeling, resource allocation algorithms, power consumption analysis, and performance evaluation.
Finally, simulation results are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the system we proposed.
We conducted new observations and analyses of two nearby supernova remnants, namely G292.0+1.8 (Cassiopeia A) and Kes 79.

We found that the two wreckages exhibit significant asymmetry between the northern and southern halves; however, we believe this is not due to the asymmetry of the explosion, but rather because of the differences in the environmental media present during the expansion of each half at the time of its formation.
For Casio A, we observed significant differences in the density structure in the line of sight towards the north side and the south side of the debris.
The northern side displays dense shell-like features, while the southern side appears more uniform, lacking distinct shell-like markings.
This indicates that the precursor star passed through a denser area on the northern side than on the southern side during its explosion.
For Kes 79, our X-ray data reveal a bright compact source located near the center of the southern half of the remnant.
We suggest that this object may be related to the central engine of a supernova event, and it could even be the neutron star itself.

Introduction: Local decodable codes (LCDs) are a type of error-correcting code in which each codeword has an associated decoding algorithm. When queried, this algorithm allows for the efficient recovery of a single bit or symbol.
Specifically, if the codeword is corrupted by at most t errors, there exists a deterministic polynomial-time algorithm that uses O(t) queries per symbol to recover the original undamaged word.
This attribute makes these encodings very useful in applications such as data storage systems, peer-to-peer networks, and streaming distribution services.
A large number of research efforts are devoted to understanding the trade-offs between coding rate, code distance, and decoder query complexity.
For example, Guruswami et al. (2005), Chan et al. (2006), and Kopparty & Saraf (2007) studied the problem of constructing low query complexity codes while maintaining high rates and distances.
Recently, some research efforts have focused on improving the known boundaries to enhance the minimum query complexity required to decode a single bit under a certain level of distortion.

These include the groundbreaking results recently achieved by Dvir et al. (2010a), which improved the previously known best upper bound proposed by Sudan et al. (2005), as well as subsequent improvements made by Dvir et al. (2011), Feldman et al. (2012), and Kopparty et al. (2013).

Introduction  
It has been suggested that interstellar dust particles can grow to millimeter sizes or larger in dense molecular clouds, as they are able to withstand destructive collisions with other particles (e.g., condensation theory; Ossenkopf & Henning 1994).

However, recent observations have shown that there are many small dust particles in dense regions where the gas density exceeds 10^6 cm^{-3} (e.g., Stepnik et al., 2003; Pagani et al., 2003), which contradicts this scenario.

To address this discrepancy, it was proposed that when the size of dust particles is comparable to the mean free path of hydrogen molecules, dust particles can be effectively destroyed through fragmentation via collisions (Ormel et al. 2007).
Another possibility is that during the collision process, dust particles do not grow, but instead break into smaller particles (for example, Blum and Wurm 2008).
If this is the case, we should see some evidence of grain destruction products in the dense cloud, such as submicron-sized fragments.

Indeed, some observational studies have reported the detection of submillimeter-wave radiation features attributed to silicate and/or carbonaceous materials in dense clouds (for example, Jones et al., 1993; Chiar et al., 1998; Kessler).

We conducted an analysis of the angular velocity distribution of the Sun based on seismic data, which is based on the assumption that its total angular momentum is conserved during the evolution of the Sun.
We found that this hypothesis leads to a good agreement between theoretical predictions and observations at all latitudes, except near the poles, where we observed significant deviations.
These differences are explained by considering the influence of the sun on the torsional oscillations in the convective envelope.
Our results indicate that these oscillations can be excited by the internal magnetic fields generated by differential rotation within the solar radiation zone.
This mechanism may also occur in other solar-type stars with strong surface magnetic activity.

We introduced the network topology and trading volume of the first experimental futures exchange, which was launched in September 2009 as part of the University of Chicago's Financial Markets Laboratory (FML).
FML aims to provide students with practical experience in the design, implementation, and operation of financial markets.
We found that the network exhibits similar small-world characteristics to those observed in other real-world networks, such as social networks and the internet.
In addition, we demonstrate the evolution of the network over time by analyzing the growth rate and degree distribution of the network.
Finally, we study the relationship between the number of transactions executed by each node and their respective degrees.
Our results indicate that nodes with a higher degree tend to trade more than nodes with a lower degree.

This discovery is significant for market design because it suggests that if traders want to maximize their trading activities, they should be incentivized to increase their connectivity within the network.
We also studied whether there are any differences between the different types of contracts traded on the exchange.

We investigated the rheology of isotropic networks formed by cross-linking actin filaments with two different concentrations of biotin-avidin linkers, using a combination of micro-rheological experiments on single filaments and macroscopic rheological measurements conducted at low frequencies (0.01-10 Hz).

We found that both microscopic and macroscopic rheology are consistent with a model of elastic networks, through which we can extract the density of connections between filaments as well as their stiffness values.

In living cells, structures of the cytoskeleton, such as stress fibers or focal adhesions, provide physical connections for cellular components and play an important role in determining the mechanical properties of the cells. [1]

We study glass transition as a collection of adhesive hard spheres, where the repulsive interactions between these spheres decay in the form of 1/r^6, with r representing the distance between the particles.

We found that the system exhibits two different relaxation processes at low temperatures: one fast process is related to the local rearrangement within strongly bonded particle clusters; the other slower process is associated with the collective motion of these clusters.

We study droplet excitations in a two-dimensional spin glass model with nearest-neighbor interactions and random ferromagnetic bonds, which is known to have an infinite number of metastable states at zero temperature.

The main goal of this paper is to experimentally explore recursion as an alternative method for querying databases, using Prolog (a declarative language) and SQL (structured query language).

We found that if peak oil occurs before 2020, it will have little impact on these variables, as there is still time to develop alternative energy sources.

However, since the peak of oil production indeed occurred after 2020 but before 2030, its impact is more significant; based on the exact date and magnitude of the oil peak, our results indicate that by 2100, temperatures could rise by 1.5°C to 3.0°C above pre-industrial levels, with associated sea level rises of up to 0.7 meters.

These findings indicate that for both nearby and distant galaxies, the amount of dust increases with the mass of the galaxy.

We analyzed the shallow decay segment in the X-ray afterglow light curve observed by Swift/XRT, based on our previous work (Zhang et al., 2006).
We found two types of shallow decay, each with different physical origins.
The first type has been widely discussed and can be explained as stemming from energy injection or re-impact.
However, we indicate that this situation cannot explain all cases of shallow decay.
In particular, it fails to take into account those shallow decays that occur late, when external impacts should have completely dissipated.

For these events, we propose an alternative explanation—second-class shallow decays—which may arise from the transition between the relativistic fireball phase and the non-relativistic jet-dominated phase.
This new explanation naturally clarifies why certain shallow decays occur only at later times, while other decays appear both early and late during the process of afterglow evolution.

We used archival data obtained from the Very Large Array (VLA) over the past 20 years to search for radio transients in the frequency range of 4 to 8 GHz, with flux densities between 0.1 and 1 mJy.
