Most of the sources in our sample are previously unarchived sources; however, we have recovered many known variable star sources, such as blazars and afterglows of gamma-ray bursts.
Our results demonstrate the strong ability to integrate large volumes of archival VLA data into a coherent dataset.

In this letter, we analyze all available archived Very Large Array (VLA) observational data since 1990.
These data were collected from various observational projects, mainly aimed at studying distant galaxies or nearby star formation regions.
However, they contain valuable information about the faint transient phenomena occurring in our galaxy.

By searching over 10,000 hours of observation time, distributed across nearly 2,000 cycles, we identified thousands of new faint radio sources that appeared only once or twice in the data set of each cycle.

Most of these sources are extragalactic, but we have also detected many objects within the Milky Way, including pulsar wind nebulae, supernova remnants, blazars, and other types of active galactic nuclei.
Many of these newly discovered sources have not been included in the existing catalog because they have a low signal-to-noise ratio, which makes them difficult to detect in individual observations.
However, by combining data from multiple eras, we can significantly improve the sensitivity of the investigation, making it capable of detecting very faint signals.

We consider the asymptotic behavior of the sample autocovariance function and spectral density function of stationary processes with regularly varying marginal distributions. These processes are driven by an infinite-order moving average process, whose coefficients have regularly varying tails.

We indicate that under certain conditions regarding the tail behavior of autoregressive moving average (ARMA) parameters, these quantities can be approximated in the sense of weak convergence by quantities from finite-order autoregressive moving average (ARMA) models.

We study the propagation of sound waves through a one-dimensional (1D) Bose-Einstein condensate gas, which is trapped by an optical lattice potential and interacts with each other via contact interactions.

However, for strong interaction strengths, phonons are scattered into higher energy bands, resulting in a decrease in sound speed compared to its non-interacting value.
The results are very consistent in the numerical calculations based on the Gross-Pitaevskii equation.

Here, I will briefly summarize the current understanding of this topic.
The evolution of galaxies is strongly influenced by their environment, but the physical mechanisms driving this process are not yet clear.
Especially, it is currently unclear how the properties of galaxies, such as morphology or star formation rate, depend on the large-scale structure of the universe.
This lecture will present the results of an ongoing research project that uses data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) to explore these issues.
The first part of my presentation will focus on the relationship between galaxy clustering and luminosity/stellar mass.
I will discuss recent research on how the properties of galaxies depend on local density.
Finally, I will present some preliminary results exploring the relationship between galaxy properties and the mass of dark matter halos.
My research is funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under grant number AST-0707766.
I am currently a postdoctoral researcher at Harvard University, collaborating with Professor David Weinberg.
I earned my doctorate at the University of California, Los Angeles, under the supervision of Dr. James Block.

We analyze the ages obtained through the method of rotating growth rings, applying this analysis to a sample of open star clusters with known ages (from the literature) in order to assess the reliability of the method and any potential systematic errors.
We found that the age estimates are usually consistent within their uncertainty range, but there is some evidence suggesting a slight bias towards younger ages compared to the true cluster ages.
This bias may be due to the fact that we used only one rotation period for each star, without considering the observed spread or variation of periods among stars of similar age.
The results presented here indicate that if all relevant sources of uncertainty are carefully considered during application, this technique can provide useful constraints on stellar ages.
Keywords: age determination, open cluster, rotation period, gyrochronology.

1 Introduction  
The age of stars plays a crucial role in many fields of astrophysics, from galactic archaeology to exoplanet science.
Accurate age data is especially needed to understand how planets form and evolve over time.
However, determining the exact age of individual stars remains challenging, as they span several orders of magnitude in mass and brightness and exhibit complex evolutionary histories.

For example, although the turnoff age of main-sequence stars can be accurately determined using luminosity measurement techniques (such as fitting theoretical isochrones to a color-magnitude diagram (CMD)), these methods cannot be easily extended beyond the red giant branch, as the effects of convection become significant in that region.

In addition, even if stellar oscillation observations allow us to detect the interiors of evolved stars, interpreting the obtained data still requires detailed modeling of the structure and evolution of each star.
Therefore, it is necessary to explore other methods to determine the ages of a large number of stars at different evolutionary stages.

Rotation chronometry provides another method for estimating age based on the rotational deceleration rate of magnetic activity cycles driven by the dynamical power generation processes at the bottom of the solar convection zone (Barnes 2003).
It has been proven that the Rossby number \( R_o \) is defined as the ratio of the rotation period \( P_{rot} \) to the timescale of convective overturning.
We reported the phenomenon of fluidizing a thin horizontal vibrated particle bed through low-frequency and low-amplitude vertical vibrations.
The system conducts experimental research by integrating high-speed video imaging with particle tracking velocimetry (PTV) technology.
We found that for sufficiently large vibration amplitudes, particles will be ejected into the air from the surface when they move upward to reach their maximum height.
This leads to the formation of a thin gas phase above the area densely accumulated at the bottom of the container.
Additionally, we observed convective rolls that transport particles throughout the depth of the bed.

These results show significant similarities to those observed in vibrating sand or glass bead beds, but there are notable differences compared to previous studies that only applied horizontal vibrations to the system.
Vibrations can lead to transitions between different states of matter, such as solid, liquid, and gas.

An especially interesting situation occurs when both the horizontal and vertical components of the driving force act simultaneously [4].
In this work, we studied the response of a thin granular layer to the simultaneous action of horizontal and vertical vibrations.
Our experiment reveals new phenomena that have not been observed in other types of driven granular media.

We present the results of the galaxy infrared (IR) characteristics obtained by comparing the predictions from a semi-analytic galaxy formation model with the observational data from the Spitzer Infrared Nearby Galaxies Survey (SINGS).
We found that our model reproduces many observed trends, including the infrared luminosity function and the correlation between the star formation rate and dust temperature.
However, we also found some inconsistencies, which indicate that further work is needed before this model can be used for detailed studies of individual objects or small samples.
The main conclusions can be summarized as follows: The predicted number at 24 micrometers is in good agreement with the number measured by Spitzer/MIPS across most of the range detected by SINGS.
Our model predicts too few low-luminosity galaxies compared to the observational results; however, due to the extremely faint flux of these systems, they may not have been detected.
The predicted dust temperature distribution is quite consistent with the observational results, although there seems to be an excess of cold dust galaxies in the simulation compared to the data.

The relationship between the predicted far-infrared color and total infrared brightness is quite consistent with observational results, but shows signs of being slightly steeper than what the data suggest.
We reported the adhesion between two surfaces made of the same material, caused by triboelectric charge and electrostatic attraction.
The experiment was conducted at room temperature using an atomic force microscope (AFM) in air on silicon wafers.
We found that the measured adhesion increased linearly with the increase of the normal load applied to the atomic force microscope (AFM) probe.
This behavior can be explained by considering the contact area and the charge density distribution in that region.
In addition, we demonstrate how adhesion depends on relative humidity.
Finally, we discuss the potential applications we have discovered.
Tribology studies the phenomena of friction, wear, and lubrication that occur when solid objects slide against each other or undergo elastic deformation under pressure.

This study is dedicated to exploring certain aspects of geometry and topology in relativistic cosmology, with particular emphasis on the role played by the Weyl tensor.

In the second section, we reviewed the basic concepts of Riemannian geometry related to our purpose; in particular, we introduced the concept of conformal vector fields and the associated energy-momentum tensor.
We also discussed how these fields can be used to construct exact solutions of the Einstein equations that describe a uniform but anisotropic universe.
In the third section, we consider the classification problem of all types of singularities that may occur in a finite amount of time within the spatially closed Friedman-Robertson-Walker (FRW) model.

We report the X-ray observation results of the strong radio-active galaxy Centaurus A (NGC 5128) nucleus using the Suzaku satellite.
The data was obtained in 2006 and 2007, during which the observation time for the source was approximately 100 kiloseconds per session.
We found that the spectrum can be well described by an absorption power-law model, with corrections for photoelectric absorption by cold gas at low energy.

No significant emission lines were detected above 3 keV. Using this spectral model, we constrained the abundance of heavy elements in the accretion flow around the supermassive black hole at the center of NGC 5128.
Specifically, we indicate that the abundance of iron cannot exceed 1.5 to 2 times its solar value relative to solar values.

We present the first results of clustering measurements for luminous red galaxies (LRGs) in the redshift range of 0.5 < z < 0.8, obtained through the AAOmega multi-object spectrograph at the Anglo-Australian Observatory.
We use data from the 2dF-SDSS LRG and QSO surveys to measure the projection correlation function wp(rp).
The observed clustering amplitude is consistent with the linear theoretical predictions based on the current cosmological model.
This result provides an important test for these models within this redshift range, as there are very few other constraints available in this range.
In addition, we found evidence of an evolution of about 200 million years in the galaxy deviation parameters between our two samples.
These results will be described in detail elsewhere.
Keywords: Luminous red star system; clusters; deviation evolution; cosmology.

1 Introduction  
Recent studies have shown that luminous red galaxies (hereinafter referred to as LRGs) selected by their optical color or near-infrared luminosity provide a powerful means for detecting large-scale structures at high redshifts (e.g., Eisenstein et al., 2001; Wake et al., 2006; Padmanabhan et al., 2007; Blake et al., 2008; Ross et al., 2008).
Their greater brightness means that they can be effectively detected even at relatively low redshifts, and their redness makes spectral identification easier.
They often reside in massive dark matter halos, which evolve slowly over cosmic timescales, making them useful tracers of potential mass distribution.

Therefore, they provide a unique opportunity to study the growth of structures and the nature of dark energy that drives its accelerated expansion (see, for example, the review by Percival & White 2009).

We report here the first measurement of the spatial clustering properties of luminous red galaxies (LRGs) in the redshift range of 0 < z < 0.8, made possible by combining data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) (York et al. 2000) and the Two Degree Field Galaxy Redshift Survey (2dFGRS) (Colless et al.).

We present the distance measurements of two galaxies, NGC 3109 and WLM, based on observations from the Hubble Space Telescope (HST).
We used HST/WFPC2 images taken through the F555W and F814W filters to search for Cepheid variables in the young open star clusters located within these galaxies.
Our investigation discovered four new Cepheid variables in NGC 3109 and one in WLM.
These five Cepheid variables are all classical pulsating stars with periods ranging from 4.5 days to 8.6 days.

According to the period-luminosity relation derived by Madore and Freedman, we found that the distance estimates for NGC 3109 and WLM are in good agreement with previous estimates obtained using other methods.
Keywords: Cepheid variable stars; open star clusters; galaxy distance scale; Hubble Space Telescope; Araucaria Project.

1. Introduction  
   Open star clusters provide an important tool for determining distances beyond our galaxy, as they contain many stars that are nearly identical in age and chemical composition.
In addition, open star clusters can be found over a wide range of galactic center radii, allowing us to probe different environments.
However, compared to field stars or globular clusters, open clusters are relatively rare celestial bodies.

Therefore, it is necessary to conduct a survey covering a large area of the sky in order to obtain a statistically significant sample of open star clusters that can be used as calibrators for cosmic distance scales.
The Arecibo project started in 1998, aiming to obtain accurate distances to nearby galaxies by measuring Cepheid variables associated with open star clusters.
This project primarily uses data collected by the WFPC2 camera of the Hubble Space Telescope.
During the 9th-10th cycles of the Hubble Space Telescope program, a total of eight fields were observed.
Each observation area covers approximately 0.25 square degrees, with the center located at the target galaxy.
For each observation area, deep exposures were taken in both the F555W and F850LP bands.
Detailed information about the project can be found in Pietrzyński et al. (2002) and the literature they cite.

We study the solidification process of a model system composed of particles interacting through repulsive soft-core potentials, subjected to external driving forces.

We demonstrated that for sufficiently large drive amplitude values, the system undergoes a phase transition and enters a state where its behavior resembles that of a coexistence phase composed of two components with different densities.
The characteristic of the low-density phase is that it relaxes to the equilibrium state in a slow manner, which can be described by mean field theory.
In contrast, the high-density phase quickly relaxes to its stable configuration.
This behavior is very similar to what happens when a colloidal suspension freezes under the influence of shear flow.

Our results indicate that this analogy may be applicable not only at the level of static characteristics but also when considering dynamic features, such as the response to disturbances or the presence of aging effects.
Finally, we discussed extending our work to more realistic models to describe the glass dynamics observed experimentally in ultracold liquids.

We introduced the concept of algebraic charge liquid, which is defined as a ground state of a Hamiltonian with local interactions that can be represented by fermionic creation and annihilation operators.
We demonstrated how to construct such models by explicitly representing a finite group G in the Hilbert space of non-spin fermions.
This result model can be exactly solved when there are no nontrivial subgroups in G.
In this case, we find that there is at least one phase transition connecting different phases characterized by different topological orders.
For example, if \( G = \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \), then our construction will yield two distinct gapped phases differentiated by their chiral center charge \( c^{-} = 0 \) or 1.

If the group \( G \) contains a non-trivial subgroup \( H \), then the system will exhibit gapless excitations corresponding to particles that transform according to the irreducible representations (irrep) of \( H \).
These results provide new insights into the classification problem of quantum many-body systems.

We study the holographic entanglement entropy in three-dimensional de Sitter space by using replication techniques and the covariant phase space method, taking into account the gravitational Chern-Simons term.
We found that the entanglement entropy does not have a logarithmic correction, which is consistent with previous results obtained by other methods.
In addition, we indicate that the first-order correction is proportional to the square root of the volume surrounded by the entangled surface.
Finally, we calculate these second-order corrections and obtain an expression that contains two terms.

We propose an optimal design method to find the best occulting masks for directly imaging exoplanets.
The proposed method is based on the concept of maximum entropy, which has been widely applied in various fields such as information theory and statistical mechanics.
We demonstrated how this concept is extended in the field of optics and proposed a new quantity called optical entropy (OE).
By using optical elements (OE), we are able to quantify the amount of information contained in each point spread function generated by different masks.
This allows us to determine the most effective mask shape for detecting faint companions around bright stars.
To demonstrate our method, we conducted numerical simulations to compare the performance of several candidate masks.
Our results indicate that the proposed method shows significant improvement over existing methods in finding the optimal mask shape for detecting faint companions around bright host stars.
The Casimir effect is one of the most important manifestations of quantum vacuum fluctuations and has been widely studied for over 50 years.

The original prediction was made by H.B.G. Casimir, who proved that two uncharged parallel conducting plates would attract each other, with the force of attraction inversely proportional to the fourth power of the distance between them.
From this work, we studied how the magnitude of the Casimir force depends on the optical properties of its boundary conditions.
We consider three different cases, corresponding to (i) a perfectly reflecting mirror, (ii) a dielectric mirror, and (iii) a metallic mirror.
In all these cases, we use Lifshitz theory to numerically calculate the Casimir energy density.
Our results indicate that the Casimir force acting between two identical mirrors can be either repulsive or attractive, depending on whether the medium between them is air or water.
The reason for this behavior is that the reflection coefficient on the mirror surface strongly depends on the surrounding medium.
The purpose of this article is to introduce the basic concepts of Riemannian geometry needed to understand the main results presented in this article.
The first part introduces some symbols and definitions used in the text.
Specifically, we define the meaning of short distance (measured by geodesic distance) or long distance between two points on an n-dimensional manifold M.

We have also introduced the concept of a local coordinate system, which allows us to describe any other point q located near p by giving the coordinates of these local charts at each point p ∈ M on the manifold M.
Finally, we briefly describe how to locally construct such a coordinate system around a given point by parallel transporting along a curve emanating from the point p.
The second part describes the concept of a vector field X defined on the entire manifold M. This is achieved by defining a mapping F: TM → R, where TM denotes the tangent bundle of M.
Then we show that if the vector field \( X \) satisfies certain conditions, there exists a unique smooth function \( f : M \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) such that \( X = \nabla f \).
Here, grad(f) denotes the gradient of f.

For example, if M is a surface embedded in R3, then X can represent the velocity of a particle moving on M. If we assume that the particle moves according to Newton's laws of motion, then the function f will correspond to the potential energy of the system under consideration.
The third part defines the concept of tensor fields as a generalization of vector fields.
The tensor field allows us to associate multiple vectors.

We believe that the two branches in the mass distribution of neutron stars are due to different formation mechanisms. One branch is formed through accretion-induced collapse (AIC) of white dwarfs, while the other branch is formed through core-collapse supernovae (CCSNe).
We demonstrate how this scenario can both explain the existence of massive pulsars and account for the lack of such objects in the observed remnants of core-collapse supernovae.
The proposed model also explains why there have been no successful attempts to detect gravitational waves emitted by AIC events so far.

Through supplementary explanations, we believe our model can clarify the apparent inconsistency between the mass inferred from observations of binary systems that include black holes or neutron stars and the mass inferred from radius measurements of isolated neutron stars.
Finally, we discuss the observational tests that could be used to validate our hypotheses.
We present new results regarding the formation of bipolar leaves from the explosion of an expanding and rotating surface ("rotational detonation").
We used two-dimensional fluid dynamics simulations to show that if these explosions are not too energetic or do not expand too quickly, they can form disks with large opening angles.
The surface of this disk is formed into a thin shell due to the rapid outward expansion of the star's outer layer; subsequently, this shell breaks apart due to Rayleigh-Taylor instability.
As the shell fragments scatter, matter falls back to the central region of the exploding star, forming two opposite jets that break out along the system's polar axis.
These jets propel the expansion of the bipolar blades.

We present the first detection of the relativistic modulated X-ray flux from the black hole candidate Sagittarius A* at the center of the Milky Way, using data obtained from observations with the Chandra and XMM-Newton satellites between 2000 and 2007.

The observed light curve shows a distinct periodic decline, with a time scale ranging from 20 minutes to several hours, which is consistent with phenomena caused by general relativity effects near the event horizon of this supermassive black hole.
We did not find any evidence of long-term changes or eruptive activity during the observation period.
These results strongly support the theoretical model that radiation is generated by accretion disk instabilities near the last stable orbit close to the central black hole.

We consider the energy-efficient modulation problem for downlink transmission in Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) networks, where each user has individual delay constraints and is equipped with rechargeable batteries that can be charged by collecting ambient radio frequency signals.
We formulate this problem as a non-cooperative game, in which users compete for limited power resources under their own constraints on transmission rate and delay.
Specifically, we demonstrate how to use convex optimization techniques to compute the Nash equilibrium of such games.
Our numerical results show that there is a significant improvement in network throughput and energy efficiency compared to traditional schemes based on fixed-rate transmission.
The proposed method also enables us to quantify the trade-offs between different performance metrics, including average packet delay, service interruption probability, and energy consumption per bit.

Through this article, we investigate the latest progress and remaining challenges of using game theory methods for energy-efficient wireless resource management (RRM) in wireless networks.
The main goal is to demonstrate how to leverage these technologies to enhance network performance and reduce power consumption at each node.

The fourth part discusses open research questions and summarizes this paper.

Introduction  
Galaxies are complex systems, and their properties largely depend on their mass, age, chemical composition, star formation history, and environment.
These physical characteristics determine many observable quantities, such as luminosity, color, morphology, and kinematics, all of which have been extensively studied over the decades.

However, it has recently become apparent that there is significant degeneracy between these observables, and therefore, without additional information about the underlying physics or geometry of the system, they cannot be uniquely determined.
For example, a galaxy's total brightness depends not only on its current star formation rate but also on its past star formation activities, which are reflected in the combined light of older stars.
Similarly, the color of a galaxy depends both on its metallicity and on the amount of dust extinction along our line of sight.
Therefore, accurate measurements of all relevant physical parameters require detailed spectral observations covering a wide range of wavelengths.

These studies are now made possible thanks to new space missions, such as GALEX, SDSS, 2MASS, the Spitzer Space Telescope, the Herschel Space Observatory, the Chandra X-ray Observatory, XMM-Newton, the Hubble Space Telescope, and most importantly, the upcoming launch of the European Space Agency's Gaia satellite.
Gaia is expected to provide astrometric positions, parallaxes, proper motions, radial velocities, and multi-band photometric data for over one billion celestial objects.

We proposed two models of such systems: (1) an analytical model based on mean field theory; (2) a simulation model constructed using the ns-2 network simulator.
The results show that the model we proposed can accurately predict message throughput under different settings.
In addition, we found that as the number of nodes increases or the average node degree decreases, the message throughput decreases.
Finally, we compared the message throughput achieved by three popular overlay routing protocols: flooding, random walk, and epidemic routing.
Our research findings indicate that when there is only one source-destination pair, the message throughput of flood transmission is higher than that of random walk and epidemic routing.
However, if multiple pairs exist simultaneously, the performance of epidemic routing outperforms flooding, as it allows messages to be forwarded along multiple paths concurrently.
We present an analysis of the kinematic Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect (kSZ) caused by electrons in our galaxy, using data from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope and the South Pole Telescope.

We use two different methods to estimate the kSZ signal; one method is based on the cross-correlation of CMB temperature anisotropy maps at 150 GHz and 3000 GHz, while the other method uses the power spectrum of CMB temperature fluctuations at 150 GHz.
The results are consistent between the two methods within their respective ranges of uncertainty.

We find that when we assume the dark matter density distribution around the Milky Way follows the Navarro-Frenk-White profile, the amplitude of the signal is very consistent with theoretical predictions.

This measurement provides new constraints on cosmological parameters, such as the Hubble constant H0 = 73 +/- 4 km s⁻¹ Mpc⁻¹, the total matter density parameter Omega_m = 0.27 +/- 0.03, and the equation of state w = -1.06 +/- 0.11.

We propose an algorithm for reconstructing a signal network, where each node is associated with multiple time series data, and we assume that only a subset of nodes is observed at any given time point.
The proposed method consists of two steps: (1) estimating the state vector by solving a sparse reconstruction problem; (2) using the estimated state as features to infer the edge set.

We demonstrate through numerical experiments on synthetic networks that our method can still accurately recover the structure and parameters of the underlying network, even when only partial system information is available.
Our results also indicate that the performance of the proposed method largely depends on whether the observation matrix can effectively capture the sparsity pattern of the true signal.
Finally, we applied this method to analyze the dynamics of protein phosphorylation in yeast cells under heat shock stress.
In particular, we have identified several key proteins involved in regulating the reaction process.
This work was supported by grant R01GM084283-01A1 from the National Institutes of Health.

We present new observations using the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) from 1.4 GHz to 8.5 GHz, which are related to the radio afterglow of the gamma-ray burst GRB030329 that occurred on March 29, 2003.
The data was collected between April 2, 2004, and May 8, 2004, which is more than a year after the outbreak incident occurred.
We found that the source is still increasing in brightness at a rate of about 0.5% per day at two frequencies.
This behavior can be interpreted as our assumption that the fireball has not yet reached its final deceleration radius.
In this case, the observed radiation will come from the expanding shell surrounding the central engine, with the material inside the shell moving at relativistic speeds.

If that's the case, our results suggest that the energy injection process leading to the late flare activities of other gamma-ray bursts may have continued to occur at distances very far from the parent system.

We present new observations and analyses that study Balmer-dominated shocks driven into dense molecular clouds by supernova remnants (SNRs), phenomena referred to as "molecular cloud shocks" or "Balmer-dominated shocks."
We found that the intermediate temperature of these impacts is between that of a typical J-type impact and a C-type impact.
The observed emission lines show a significant P-Cygni profile, accompanied by blueshifted absorption features, indicating speeds of up to 100 km/s.
These results indicate that the transition zone is located at the interface between the shocked gas and the unshocked ambient medium.
In addition, we found that the Hα line profile width at the center of SNR W28 has increased.
This suggests that the density structure of the surrounding environment may be more complex than previously thought.

Our research indicates that shocks from molecular clouds dominated by the Balmer lines can provide important information about the physical conditions of the interstellar medium surrounding young supernova remnants.
We present the results of an analysis of high-resolution spectra obtained through HST/STIS, which come from four nearby (z = 1020 cm^-3) supernova sites located within 0.01 to 0.20 parsecs.
Such density is expected in the later stages of stellar evolution if these explosions occur after the low-speed "uplift" eruptions.
In addition, we observed narrow emission features, which may be related to shock heating caused by the expansion of the supernova remnant and the circumstellar medium (CSM).

We report for the first time the detection of secondary cosmic microwave background polarization induced by Faraday rotation (FR) in galaxy clusters, using data from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope Polarimeter (ACTPol).
We detected FR-induced polarized radiation in two galaxy clusters, ACT-CL J0102-4915 and ACT-CL J0546-5345, with angular scales corresponding to multipole numbers = 100-1000.
The observed signals are consistent with the theoretical predictions based on numerical simulations of the magnetized star cluster atmosphere.

This measurement provides an important test for our understanding of the magnetic fields in galaxy clusters and their impact on cosmological observables, such as the temperature anisotropy of the cosmic microwave background radiation and E-mode polarization.

In addition, we report the upper limit of FR-induced polarized radiation from other galaxy clusters that have not been individually detected due to low signal-to-noise ratio or limited observational range.

These results will be helpful for future research, particularly regarding the impact of FR on the Cosmic Microwave Background polarization maps produced by upcoming experiments such as the Planck satellite and the Simons Observatory.

We used data from the Chandra X-ray Observatory to measure the Hubble constant and the equation of state parameter \( w_0 \) for the most massive and dynamically relaxed galaxy clusters in the universe.
We have set stricter constraints on the nature of dark energy using these results.

The sample consists of eight galaxy clusters with redshifts between 0.3 and 1.2, which were observed using the Chandra satellite as part of our ongoing research project on the evolution of scaling relations in galaxy clusters at high redshifts.
Using the hydrostatic equilibrium model, we measure the gas mass fraction of each system at r500 (the radius where the mean density is 500 times the critical density).
These values are combined with the independent estimates of the total gravitational mass obtained by other teams through weak lensing analysis.
This results in a value for H0 of 70 +/- 6 km s^-1 Mpc^-1, assuming a flat prior for the two parameters.
If we assume a Gaussian prior based on previous measurements of the Hubble constant and the cosmic baryon content, then this measurement result becomes H0 = 68 ± 6 km s⁻¹ Mpc⁻¹.
The driving mechanism of jets and outflows remains an unresolved mystery, especially in cases where there is no obvious central engine, such as a black hole or a protostar.
In this work, we propose that magnetic reconnection may be the cause of the jets and outflows that initiate the star formation process.

We demonstrated that magnetic reconnection can accelerate particles to relativistic energies via shock acceleration driven by reconnection current sheets (RCS). This process is achieved through Fermi acceleration.
Accelerated electrons will generate synchrotron radiation, which may explain the jets and outflows observed in radio observations.
In addition, the high-energy protons generated by RCS also contribute to non-thermal radiation through inverse Compton scattering with background photons.
Finally, we discuss how our model explains some observational features of jets and outflows.
Keywords: magnetic reconnection; jet; particle acceleration; shock wave; synchrotron radiation; non-thermal radiation.

The effects of three different sugars (trehalose, maltose, and sucrose) on the structure and dynamics of lysozyme were studied through molecular dynamics simulations conducted at 300 K, with each case simulated for 100 nanoseconds.
The results show that all these sugar molecules can stabilize proteins to some extent and resist heat denaturation, but it was found that trehalose is the most effective among these sugars.
The glucose alcohol molecules form hydrogen bonds with polar and non-polar amino acid residues, thereby increasing the number of surrounding water molecules.
This increases the thickness of the protein's hydration shell and the total solvent-accessible surface area.
It also reduced the root mean square deviation between the initial structure and the final structure, indicating its ability to maintain the natural conformation of the protein.
Maltose and sucrose are less efficient than trehalose because they form fewer hydrogen bonds with proteins.
In addition, their presence leads to a slight decrease in the radius of gyration and the end-to-end distance of the protein.
In this work, we re-examine some issues related to network traffic sampling and export performance, particularly the packet loss rate (PLR) and flow sampling accuracy (FSA).
We first propose an analytical model to study the PLR (Packet Loss Rate) under different traffic conditions and with different sampling rates.
Based on our analysis results, we propose a new method to estimate FSA, which uses only one parameter – the average number of flows per second.

Finally, through extensive experiments on real-world data and synthetic datasets, we demonstrate that our proposed estimation method is accurate enough to serve as a practical tool for evaluating network monitoring systems.
The remainder of this article is organized as follows.
In the second section, we introduced work related to traffic sampling and export.
In the third part, we describe our experimental environment.
In Section 4, we analyze the relationship between PLR and sampling rate.
According to the analysis results presented in Section 4, we estimate the FSA in Section 5.
In the sixth section, we evaluate the effectiveness of the estimation method we proposed through extensive experiments.
Finally, the conclusion is drawn in the seventh part.

We present new observational results of the sunspots between two networks in the active region NOAA AR 12192, obtained using the Atacama Large Millimeter/Submillimeter Array (ALMA) on May 24 and 25, 2013.
The first sunspot was observed for about 3 hours, during which time it rotated more than 90 degrees.
We found that this sunspot is composed of multiple magnetic flux tubes from different directions.
In addition to these features, we also observed an expanded bright region between the main sunspot shadows.
This feature was previously reported as a penumbral filament, but our data did not show evidence of such a structure.
On the contrary, we interpret this feature as a coronal rain patch.
The second sunspot was observed for only 1 hour before being obscured by the Earth's atmosphere.
During this observation period, the sunspot rotated less than 30 degrees.
Our analysis shows that both sunspots are surrounded by a dark band, which may be related to the moat around the large sunspot.

We present the results obtained by applying the semi-analytic code VESPA to simulate galaxy evolution in millennium simulations, including the effects of chemical enrichment and dust extinction on their observational characteristics.

We have demonstrated that our model reproduces many observational trends of different types of galaxies at z=0 (such as the luminosity function), while also predicting some new trends that can be verified through future surveys (such as Euclid or LSST).

Especially, we found that the predicted number density of massive, stationary galaxies is too high compared to the observed results; if active galactic nucleus (AGN) feedback is more effective than assumed here, this issue might be alleviated.

Our predictions are consistent with current estimates of the cosmic star formation rate density (SFRD) at redshift around 4.5, although beyond that redshift, they tend to slightly overestimate this value.
In low-mass galaxies (Mstar < 10^10 Msun), there seems to be an excess of blue galaxies relative to red galaxies in the actual universe compared to our simulations.

This may indicate that our treatment of supernova feedback and/or reionization physics needs improvement, or that these processes have been affected by baryonic effects not included in our simulations.
The effects of silver and indium on the magnetic properties, resistivity (ER), and Hall coefficient (RH) of La2/3Ca1/3MnO3 were studied.

Research has found that both silver and indium doping can lower the critical temperature Tc, increase the critical current density Jc, and enhance the pinning force density Fp.
Silver-doped samples show a higher critical current density (Jc) than indium-doped samples at low temperatures, but exhibit a lower value at high temperatures.
These results can be explained by considering the different effects of silver ions and indium ions on the microstructure and their influence on the concentration of oxygen vacancies.

The field of astronomical research has a vast discovery space and is conducting many different types of surveys across all wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum.

In this presentation, I will discuss how wide-field optical imaging surveys are used to discover new types of celestial objects in our universe, such as quasars, galaxies, galaxy clusters, supernovae, gamma-ray bursts, etc., and how these surveys provide data to advance our understanding of dark energy that is driving the acceleration of the universe.

This lecture will provide examples of some recent results obtained from current and past survey data, including the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), Pan-STARRS1, the Dark Energy Survey (DES), and the VISTA Kilo-degree Infrared Galaxy Survey (VIKING).

We studied the anisotropy of mesoscopic superconducting films in AC response, focusing on the direction of the applied magnetic field, using numerical simulations based on disordered metal semiclassical theory and the Usadel equation.
We found that the magnitude of the real part of the complex conductivity tensor strongly depends on the angle between the current density vector and the external magnetic field.
The imaginary part of the ac conductivity does not show such dependence.
This behavior can be understood by considering the effect of the magnetic field on the distribution function of Andreev bound states.
Our results are related to experiments conducted on thin film structures, in which the transport properties are very sensitive to the direction of the sample relative to the applied magnetic field.
In recent years, mesoscopic superconducting systems have been widely studied due to their potential applications as quantum devices.

We propose a method that uses variational techniques to assimilate magnetic field observation data into a numerical model.

The method is applied to a simple model problem, in which we consider the evolution of a single component of the magnetic vector potential in a two-dimensional domain with periodic boundary conditions.
We use this example as a testing platform to explore how the choice of different observation operators affects the quality of the resulting analysis field.

In particular, we compared the results obtained by directly applying our algorithm on the state variable (magnetic vector potential) with those obtained by first projecting it onto a set of basis functions, which are the best functions chosen for representing the solution at each time step.
Our experiments show that the results produced by these two methods are similar, but the latter can lead to significant computational savings.

Finally, we demonstrate the practicality of our method by conducting a series of twin experiments, in which synthetic magnetometer measurements are used to update the initial conditions of the simulations.
We studied both theoretically and numerically the effect of spatial dispersion (SD) on the shape of optical pulses propagating through InGaAs/GaAs quantum wells (QWs).
We indicate that spatial dispersion (SD) leads to significant changes in the temporal characteristics of the transmitted pulse, which can be used for its characterization.
The result is obtained by solving Maxwell's equations using the finite difference time domain method under periodic boundary conditions.
Research shows that the presence of SD leads to the emergence of additional peaks on both sides of the main peak of the transmitted pulse.
These peaks become more pronounced with the increase of the quantum well width.
Keywords: light propagation, finite difference time domain method, quantum well, spatial dispersion.

We present a set of new measurements for galaxy rotation widths (W20) and surface brightness (SB) selected from the 7th data release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, with inclinations ranging from 30° to 80°.
We found that there is a strong correlation between W20 and SB at a fixed luminosity, but the correlation with galaxy mass is either very weak or nonexistent.
Even when we limit our analysis to late-type spiral galaxies known to have flat rotation curves, this correlation still exists.

These results indicate that the scatter observed in the Tully-Fisher relation may primarily be due to variations in surface brightness (SB) among galaxies of similar brightness, rather than differences in their mass.
Additionally, we indicate that this effect can explain why previous studies have not found a significant dependence of the slope angle on the TF relationship.
Finally, we demonstrated how these correlations affect the estimation of the Hubble constant derived from TF relationships.
Our research findings also explain the significant differences in the values obtained by different authors when selecting samples over different incline angle ranges.

We considered two types of observationally indistinguishable dark energy models, but they have different physical origins; one is due to vacuum fluctuations, while the other is an effective field theory description as a quantum gravity effect.
In both of these cases, there exists a parameter space where the predictions for cosmic evolution are consistent with the current observational results within the range of experimental uncertainty.
However, if future experiments can measure the equation of state of dark energy more accurately, there may be an opportunity to distinguish between these two scenarios.

We present the results of an optical Integral Field Spectroscopy (IFS) survey aimed at searching for high-redshift Damped Lyman-alpha galaxies (DLA).
The sample consists of 16 strong Mg II absorption line DLAs with redshifts between 2 and 4, selected from quasar spectra observed with the Keck telescope.

We used the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph on the Gemini North telescope located at an altitude of 8 meters to obtain spatially resolved observational data in a 1 square arcsecond region around each absorber.
Our IFS data is used to study the kinematics of these absorbers, as well as their physical properties, such as metallicity and dust content.
In addition, we will compare the new measurement results with previous studies based on single-aperture spectrophotometry.
This work is part of the Gemini Observatory project GN-2007B-Q-206.
Keywords: High-redshift universe; galaxy evolution; absorber-galaxy relationship.

We report on multi-wavelength observations of the X-ray, optical, and radio afterglow of the short hard gamma-ray burst (GRB) 050724, detected by the Swift satellite on July 24, 2005, at 07:24:06 UTC.
The instantaneous launch lasted approximately 1 second, with an average photon energy of E = 300 keV, within the range of 15-350 keV.

We found that within the time scale of 10 to 1000 seconds after the outbreak, the time decay index is about 1.2, which indicates that this event belongs to the ultra-long gamma-ray burst (GRB) category.
In addition, we have detected potential re-brightening features that may occur on a timescale of about 100 seconds after the outbreak.
Our spectral analysis indicates that the spectrum can be well fitted using a single power law model and a broken power law model.
However, when comparing the best-fit parameters, their error ranges are found to be consistent with each other.
Using our multi-wavelength dataset, we estimate that the total energy associated with this event is approximately 3 x 10^44 erg.

We propose a novel exact solution to Einstein's field equations, which is applicable to stationary axisymmetric spacetimes with two interchanged Killing vectors, generated by applying a non-homogeneous framework transformation (NFT) to known vacuum solutions.
This NFT is constructed using a hypothetical indicator coefficient, which relies solely on an arbitrary radial coordinate function.
We demonstrated how this method can be used to generate a family of black hole solutions with different horizon topologies.
In particular, we have discovered a new rotating black ring solution with a circular horizon.
These solutions were previously obtained as the limits of static black rings, but our method allows us to directly obtain these solutions without any additional assumptions or approximations.
Finally, we discuss some open questions related to these results.

PACS numbers: 04.20.-q, 11.10.-z, 98.80.Cq

I. Introduction Note
The study of exact solutions to Einstein's equations has played a key role in understanding many aspects of general relativity.
However, constructing such solutions is often difficult, as it requires solving complex nonlinear partial differential equations.
When considering situations that are interesting from a physical standpoint, this problem becomes more challenging, rather than just involving cases of rotation and/or matter fields.
However, there are several techniques that can generate new solutions in different categories starting from simpler solutions.
One of the most powerful methods is to transform the original solution into another solution through the so-called non-complete framework transformation [1].
This transformation preserves certain geometric properties of spacetime while altering others; see [2] -

For example, if the transformed solution satisfies the vacuum Einstein equations, then the original solution also satisfies it.

For this work, we apply non-complete frame transformations to the known vacuum solutions of the Einstein equations to generate new exact solutions that describe stationary axisymmetric spacetimes: that is, spacetimes that acknowledge at least two independent Kirchhoff vector fields, whose orbits are closed curves [6].
Static axisymmetric spacetimes play an important role in astrophysics, as they describe the external gravitational fields of rotating objects such as stars, planets, and black holes.

The Karlsruhe Tritium Neutrino Experiment (KATRIN) is currently under construction at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology in Germany.
It can achieve unprecedentedly precise measurements of the electronic energy spectrum near the endpoint by combining an electrostatic retarding spectrometer with a magnetic filter.
The measurement aims to determine the absolute value of the effective electron antineutrino mass mneff, with a statistical uncertainty of 0.2 eV/c² or better.
Through this contribution, we demonstrate the expected sensitivity of KATRIN to mneff and the potential contributions from right-handed currents in beta decay.
We indicate that these sensitivities are primarily determined by system uncertainties, which can be controlled within the required experimental precision range.

This leads us to conclude that KATRIN has a promising outlook for precisely determining mneff, in order to test whether it aligns with the predictions of supersymmetry and other standard model extensions.

Affinity Propagation (AP) is a clustering algorithm that has been shown to be effective in many applications, including bioinformatics and computer vision.
However, the AP algorithm requires the number of clusters as an input parameter, and this parameter may sometimes be unknown in advance.

Based on this work, we propose a new method based on constrained optimization techniques, which aims to automatically determine the optimal number of clusters using only pairwise similarity information between samples.

We demonstrated how our method can be applied to several problems related to gene expression analysis, such as identifying co-expressed genes or recognizing differentially expressed genes under multiple conditions.
Our results indicate that the method we proposed outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and robustness.
The source code used to generate all the experiments presented here will be available at http://bitbucket.org/juanlorenzo/softconstraint-clustering/wiki/Home.

We present an analysis aimed at calibrating the mid-infrared (MIR) star formation rate indicators using data obtained from the Spitzer and Herschel space telescopes, as well as ground-based facilities like the infrared array camera on the Hubble Space Telescope.

We used a set of sample galaxies that have high signal-to-noise detections in all four IRAC bands (3.6-8 microns). These data were used to estimate the total infrared luminosity through spectral energy distribution fitting techniques.

The sample consists of 29 nearby star-forming galaxies, which exhibit a wide range of variations in physical properties, including stellar mass, dust temperature, metallicity, and specific star formation rate.

Using these observations, we derived an empirical relationship between the mid-infrared (MIR) emission characteristics and the total infrared luminosity, which can be used to estimate the infrared luminosity (LIR) over a wide range without requiring any assumptions about the shape or slope of the spectral energy distribution (SED) of the galaxies.
We report X-ray timing observations of the pulsar candidate PSR J1930+1855 located at the center of the supernova remnant (SNR) G54.1+0.
This source was discovered by Chandrasekhar and confirmed as a pulsar by XMM-Newton, but its rotation period is not stable on time scales exceeding one day.
We conducted two sets of targeted RXTE observations to further investigate this behavior.
In both cases, we found that the pulse frequency steadily decreased during the observation process.
This trend can be well described by an exponential decay model, and we found that the characteristic time scales are 1.1 days and 0.7 days, respectively.

We found that all the star clusters, except for one, are consistent with the local stationary standard; however, we also found evidence suggesting that two of these star clusters may be on a trajectory that could take them out of our galaxy over the course of several billion years.
These results indicate that there is no significant difference in kinematics between open clusters and globular clusters; both types appear to have similar characteristics.
The only exception seems to be the open star cluster M67, whose velocity vector points away from us, towards the constellation Cetus.
This result indicates that this open star cluster has been expelled from its parent galaxy during the process of encountering another galaxy.
Based on Hipparcos data and recent measurements of the Sun's motion relative to the Local Standard of Rest (LSR), we provide new results regarding the Sun's offset from the Galactic plane.
We found that the Sun has shifted approximately 0.5 milliarcseconds in the direction of the constellation Cetus, which is consistent with previous estimates obtained using different methods.
The observed displacement can be explained as the result of the gravitational potential of the Milky Way and the peculiar velocity of the local group relative to the Milky Way acting together.

We analyzed N-body simulations to understand how evaporation affects the mass function (MF) of globular clusters (GCs).

We found that, consistent with previous research, evaporation causes star clusters to preferentially lose stars at the low mass end, thereby steepening the slope of the mass function (MF) towards lower masses.

However, we demonstrate that this effect is offset by two competing processes: dynamic friction more effectively removes high-mass stars than low-mass stars; and the core collapse driven by the relaxation effect increases the central density of the cluster, making it harder for high-mass stars to escape.
The final result is strongly influenced by the initial concentration of the clusters, but the slope that typically results is shallower than that observed in real global clusters.
This indicates that other processes are needed to explain the shape of the observed mass function (MF).

The origin of the most massive celestial bodies remains an unsolved mystery in astrophysics, as well as their role in shaping the evolution of galaxies.
In this lecture, I will introduce recent research findings and discuss how we use observations to constrain theoretical models of these celestial bodies' formation.
The first part of my presentation will focus on the observational characteristics of young massive clusters (YMCs) discovered at high redshift z>6-7.
These young massive clusters (YMCs) can have a mass of up to \(10^8\) solar masses and a size of about 1 kpc.
They seem to be very compact compared to the local starburst galaxies, such as Ap 220 or M82, which typically contain a much lower stellar density.

We found that the observed size-mass relationship of these distant young star clusters is in very good agreement with the predictions from numerical simulations of turbulent gas clouds collapsing under self-gravity.
This indicates that vortices played an important role in the early stage of star cluster formation.
However, it is currently unclear whether all massive stars form in the large clusters observed at high redshift.
We reported the use of neutral atoms as probes to measure the electric field generated by surface contaminants.

The technology is based on measuring the Stark shift of atomic resonance lines caused by the application of an electric field, which has previously been used to study electric fields near surfaces in liquid helium temperatures or high vacuum environments.
We have extended this method to measure electric fields over a wide range of temperatures (4 K - 300 K) and pressures (10^-6 Torr - atmospheric pressure).

This work opens up new possibilities for detecting electric fields in many different systems, including biological samples where traditional techniques are limited.

We report the discovery and characterization of USco 1606-1935, an unusual wide low-mass triple system in which two M-type dwarfs orbit each other with an approximate period of 2 years, separated by about 100 astronomical units (approximately 33 light years).
The third component is a late-type K star, which has a wider orbit around the two celestial bodies, and the minimum mass of this companion star is 0.7 times that of the Sun.
We use near-infrared spectroscopy to determine the spectral types of all three components and their radial velocities.
Our research findings indicate that the total mass of the inner binary star is only 0.3 solar masses, making it one of the lowest mass binaries known.
This makes USco 1606-1935 an ideal target for future studies of planet formation around very low-quality stars.
Furthermore, we have observed a significant orbital eccentricity in the outer orbit, which may be caused by tidal interactions between the close binary and its distant third companion.

We consider the statistical properties of non-stationary random acoustic waves and electromagnetic waves, primarily analyzing them through their correlation functions, power spectra, and probability density functions (PDFs).

We study the process of generating large-scale magnetic fields in astrophysical plasmas with very small magnetic Prandtl numbers, where the magnetic Prandtl number is Pm = ν/η ≪ 1 (ν is the viscosity and η is the resistivity).
We consider two different types of flows related to this issue: spiral-driven turbulence and convection-driven turbulence.

In both cases, we find that the contribution to the average electromotive force comes from several terms, which have different scales as functions of the Reynolds number Re = UL/ν and the magnetic Reynolds number Rm = URm/η.
Here, U, L, and Rm represent the characteristic velocity, characteristic length, and characteristic magnetic field scale, respectively.
For the spiral-driven turbulence, these contributions can be divided into three categories: the first category includes all terms that are proportional to Re(Rm)−1/2.
These terms have been studied by many authors using various methods, including direct numerical simulations.
They represent the contribution of spiral motion to the so-called α effect.
The second category includes all terms that are proportional to Re^(1/2) (Rm)^(−1/4).
This indicates the influence of helicity on the nonlinear evolution of magnetic fluctuations.
Finally, there is an additional third category that includes all terms proportional to \( Re^{3/4} (Rm)^{-3/8} \).
It describes the effect of helicity on the linear growth rate of magnetic waves.

We present recent near-infrared (NIR) spectral observations obtained using Keck II/DEIMOS, which cover the entire optical range of the nearby spiral galaxy M33, down to its last isophote measured at 25 mag arcsec^-2 in the B band.
We also used archival data obtained from the infrared array camera on the Spitzer Space Telescope for our research.
The main objective of this work is to study how star formation occurs at the edge of the galactic disk and affects the surrounding interstellar medium.

Our results indicate that there are two distinct components along the line of sight toward M33: one is an extended component associated with diffuse ionized gas and young stars, and the other is a compact component primarily composed of an older stellar population.
Using these near-infrared spectra, we have derived the radial distributions of several physical parameters in the face-on view of the M33 disk, such as electron density, temperature, and opacity.
These spectra reveal interesting trends in the characteristics of interstellar matter in different regions of the Milky Way.

We present new observational results regarding the molecular gas in the central region of the nearby galaxy NGC 891, obtained using the IRAM 30-meter telescope at millimeter wavelengths of 1 mm and 3 mm.
The data reveals a widespread distribution of dense (n(H2) ~ 10^4 cm^-3) and warm (T ~ 50K) molecular gas associated with the optical disk of this edge-on spiral galaxy.

We found that the distribution of molecular gas has two distinct components: one component is closely related to the dust lane seen in the visible light images, while the other component extends into the surrounding interstellar medium.
The components of the latter have been detected by other authors before, but our high-resolution data allow us to decompose it into individual clouds.
In addition, we have detected several compact sources in the plane of the Milky Way, which may be young star formation regions.
These results indicate that there may be a rich reservoir of molecular material outside the main part of galaxies like NGC 891.

We present the radio characteristics of 38 quasars with broad absorption lines in their spectra through X-ray spectral energy distribution (SED). These quasars were selected from the quasar catalog of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 5 and observed by Chandra and/or XMM-Newton.
We found that these sources typically exhibit a steep radio to infrared continuous spectrum, weak or absent emission lines in the ultraviolet band, and a strong soft excess below 1 keV.
Most of the samples in our study show clear evidence of intrinsic reddening, as indicated by the presence of deep ultraviolet dips and the high values of Balmer decrement.
Through addition, we detected several objects that exhibit an extremely flat radio to X-ray slope, indicating relativistic beaming effects.

These results indicate that BAL quasars represent an important phase in the evolution of luminous active galactic nuclei, during which their central regions undergo rapid changes in physical conditions.

The rate at which new mutations become fixed in a population is determined by the balance between natural selection and genetic drift, but how these forces interact to shape the evolution of proteins remains unclear.
Here, we demonstrate that neutral genetic drift can accelerate the fixation of beneficial mutations in genes located in regions important for coding protein functions.

We used deep mutational scanning technology to measure the effects of all possible single amino acid substitutions across the entire sequence space of two enzymes (T4 lysozyme and TEM-1 β-lactamase) on their adaptability.
By combining these data with population genetics simulations, we found that neutral genetic drift increased the probability of fixing beneficial mutations at the active sites of these two enzymes.
This effect is particularly significant when the number of available adaptive mutations is low in each generation or when there are many competing deleterious mutations present.
Our results indicate that neutral genetic drift may play an underappreciated role in shaping the evolution of proteins.
This study investigates the effect of photon quantum on the physiological responses of seedlings under nickel (Ni2+) stress.

The results show that different treatments have a significant impact on growth and photosynthetic characteristics, particularly after 24 hours of exposure to high concentrations of Ni2+. Compared with the control group, the height of the seedlings decreased by 39% under the treatment of 100 μM Ni2+; however, after being exposed to red light (RL), the height of the seedlings increased by 20%.
By adding, the root length decreased by 44% compared to the control plants, but increased by 25% after RL illumination.
In addition, due to the toxicity of Ni2+, the chlorophyll content per unit leaf area decreased by 42%, while the application of RL resulted in a 34% increase in chlorophyll content.

Additionally, in plants treated with 100 μM Ni2+, the net photosynthetic rate (Pn), stomatal conductance (gs), intercellular CO2 concentration (Ci), transpiration rate (Tr), and water use efficiency (WUE) decreased to 46%, 49%, 50%, 51%, and 53%, respectively. In contrast, when exposed to red light (RL), they increased by 29%, 28%, 30%, 31%, and 32%, respectively.
These research results indicate that the application of RL can alleviate the effects of Ni2+ toxicity.
The Spitzer Bright Galaxy Survey (SBF) is an all-sky survey conducted using the infrared array camera on the Spitzer Space Telescope, with wavelengths of 3.6, 4.5, 5.8, and 8 microns.

The design of SBF aims to provide deep infrared photometric measurements to support research on extragalactic systems, thereby complementing existing optical surveys such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.
The dataset contains images from IRAC channel 1 (3.6 microns), channel 2 (4.5 microns), channel 3 (5.8 microns), and channel 4 (8 microns).
Each image was processed using the MOPEX software package developed by the Spitzer Science Center.
These images can be obtained from the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED).
For more information about this project, please visit http://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/SPITZER/docs/sbf/sbf-intro.html.

The initial conditions are based on planetary migration models, in which Neptune migrated outward by about 30 astronomical units and then was halted at its current position.

The detection of carbon monoxide (CO) has been widely applied over the past few decades to study the properties of cold neutral atoms and molecular gas in galaxies at different times in the universe, as it is one of the most abundant molecules in space.
However, CO is difficult to observe directly due to its lack of an electric dipole moment, and its emission is very weak.

In addition, the excitation temperature of the lowest rotational energy level of CO is usually quite low, so the frequencies of these transitions exceed the frequency range accessible to ground-based telescopes operating at millimeter wavelengths.

Therefore, our understanding of the physical conditions in the dense star formation regions of galaxies mostly comes from studies of other molecular gas indicators, including HCN, H2S, CS, CH3OH, H2O, and OH+.

We analyzed the optical and infrared photometric data obtained during the outburst of the dwarf nova system V2051 Oph in recent years (2006-2008). This system is one of the three known systems that have experienced both superoutbursts and normal outbursts simultaneously.
We found that the light curve of this celestial body has many similarities with the observational results of other SU UMa-type systems, but there are also some significant differences.

However, it is important to note that the orbital period of V2051 Oph is significantly longer than that of most other SU UMa stars, which will reduce the mass transfer rate by about ten times.

We present the results of the ground state energy and wave function of positronium obtained by solving the relativistic Schrödinger equation with a Coulomb potential using variational methods.
The calculation is carried out under two different approximations, namely the non-relativistic limit (NR) and first-order perturbation theory (PT1).
In the NR approximation, we use a Hylleraas-type trial wave function that includes spin-dependent terms up to the second power of the interparticle distance.
We also use this wave function to calculate the expectation value of the kinetic energy operator.

In the PT1 approximation, we use Hylleraas-type trial wave functions, including spin correlation terms, up to the third power of the interparticle distance, while using a Dirac orbital for one electron as the basis set.
The binding energy value we calculated is very consistent with the previously reported results.

We introduce the concept of "abstract factorial," which is a function that can efficiently represent and manipulate sets of integers.
We demonstrate how to implement these functions using standard data structures such as hash tables or trees.

Finally, we demonstrate several applications of this new category as objects, including a fast algorithm for computing the number of integer partitions with finite parts (also known as the "second kind of Stirling numbers") and an algorithm for calculating the number of ways to cover a rectangular board with tiles of different sizes.
The concept of abstract factorial and its implementation in existing data structures (such as hash tables or binary search trees) is introduced together.

The factorial is essentially a function that maps each positive integer \( n \) to another object \( f(n) \), referred to as the "value" of the factorial at \( n \). Such a value can satisfy two properties:

First, they should form a sequence of non-negative integers whose sum grows exponentially; that is, there exists some constant c > 0 such that for all sufficiently large n, the values of any factorial satisfy |f(n)| <= cn^c. Secondly, the values of different factorials cannot overlap too frequently; more specifically, if f(n1) = f(n2), then n1 and n2 must differ by at least a fixed value d.

We studied the distribution of the largest fragments during the fragmentation process, which is an important quantity for understanding how to optimize data transmission in networks and storage systems.

We demonstrated that this distribution can be approximated by a power law, with an exponent of 1 + 1/(2 - p), where p refers to the probability of merging into one when two fragments are adjacent on the disk (the so-called "merging parameter").

In many applications involving network data transmission and distributed storage systems, it is useful to understand how large the maximum fragmentation may become during the evolution of the system.

For example, if a network node must transmit a certain amount of information within a given time limit, then understanding the proportion of total data that needs to be transmitted at any moment may help improve performance.
Similarly, in a distributed storage system, understanding the expected size of the maximum fragment can determine how much space each node should allocate for storing replicas.

The geochemical behavior of the two radioactive elements, uranium (U) and thorium (Th), is discussed, along with their impact on the origin and evolution of the crust and biological evolution.
The chemical properties between these two elements are similar; however, they have different physical characteristics that affect their geological behavior.
The atomic number of uranium is 92, with a half-life of 4.5 billion years, while the atomic number of thorium is 90, with a half-life of 1.4 billion years.
These two elements naturally occur in the crust, but their concentration varies depending on the type of rock.
They can be found in igneous rocks such as granite or basalt, where they form minerals such as uranium ore or thorium ore.

These minerals may also contain other trace metals, including lead, silver, gold, copper, zinc, arsenic, selenium, molybdenum, cadmium, mercury, bismuth, antimony, tellurium, cobalt, nickel, manganese, iron, vanadium, chromium, tungsten, titanium, zirconium, niobium, tantalum, hafnium, osmium, iridium, platinum, palladium, rhodium, ruthenium, and iridium.
Uranium and thorium are also found in sedimentary rocks such as sandstone, shale, limestone, dolomite, gypsum, anhydrite, salt layers, and evaporites.
Sedimentary rocks are formed through the process of weathering when water erodes.

We present new multi-wavelength observations of the debris disk surrounding the nearby star AU Mic, which is located in the Microscopium constellation and is approximately 10 million years old (about 25 parsecs away).
The system has undergone extensive research for decades, utilizing ground-based optical imaging technology as well as space-based infrared photometric measurements and spectral analysis.
We used the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) of the Hubble Space Telescope to obtain high-resolution images in the near-infrared to study the dust distribution on small scales.

These data were supplemented by observations from the archival Spitzer Infrared Array Camera (IRAC), the Hubble Space Telescope's Photodetector Array Camera and Spectrograph (PACS), and the Submillimeter Array (SMA), which detected larger spatial scales.
Our results show that there is a large amount of cold dust within 1 AU of the central star, but no evidence of warm dust emission was found beyond this radius.
This indicates that the inner edge of the outer disk may be truncated due to the tidal forces exerted by the planetary candidate AU Mic b.

We present new observations obtained from the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), which reveal an extended disturbed molecular gas region surrounding the active galactic nucleus (AGN) of NGC 5194, also known as M51a or the Whirlpool Galaxy.
The active galactic nucleus is located at the center of this interacting galaxy pair and is classified as a Seyfert 2 type based on optical spectroscopy.
We detected two prominent dust lanes extending from the northeast and southwest directions along the minor axis of the active galactic nucleus.

Our ALMA data indicate that the distribution of dense molecular gas traced by the emission lines of HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), and CS(2-1) shows a ring-like structure around the active galactic nucleus.
This feature seems to be formed by powerful jets driven by active galactic nuclei (AGN).

We have proposed the first precise solution for a rapidly rotating neutron star surrounded by a magnetic field, where the angle between the rotation axis and the magnetic axis can be arbitrary. This solution is axisymmetric, stationary, and represents a force-free magnetic field structure.
The model is based on the assumption that the surface of the star is covered by a thin layer of plasma, which co-rotates with the star at all latitudes.
We demonstrated how to use this solution to calculate the X-ray light curves produced by hot spots located at different latitudes on the surface of a star.

In particular, we show that if we assume the two emission components come from two pole-symmetric hotspots located near the magnetic poles, the observed peak phase difference between soft X-rays (0.5-2 keV) and hard X-rays (2-10 keV), as well as their relative amplitudes, can be very accurately reproduced.

This result indicates that the observed X-ray pulse may be caused by the rotation modulation of the local emission rate, rather than the Doppler effect caused by the overall motion of the material within the emission region.
Keywords: force field, pulsar wind nebula

We present multi-instrument observational results on solar coronal plasma flows, which are obtained by combining data from the Extreme Ultraviolet Imager (EUVI) on STEREO-A and STEREO-B with data from the Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager (HMI), the Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA), and the Interface Region Imaging Spectrograph (IRIS).
The EUV imaging shows that from February 24 to March 1, 2011, the bright ring-like structure at the edge clearly exhibited a counterclockwise rotation.
We found that this rotation can be interpreted as a result of the relative motion of two spacecraft along their orbits around the Sun.

To supplement, we used HMI magnetograms to calculate the magnetic flux density distribution on the surface of the Sun.
Our results reveal that the plasma flow patterns are closely related to the magnetic field in the photosphere.

The purpose of this lecture is to present some of the latest results concerning the relationship between integrability in quantum field theory, statistical mechanics, or mathematical physics, and the special geometric structures (complex algebraic curves) associated with these models.

We will discuss how to utilize such geometric structures to accurately solve certain physical problems by employing techniques from algebraic geometry, such as Riemann surfaces, Theta functions, and so on.
We will also explain why many interesting integrable models seem to possess a potential structure of Riemann surfaces.
Finally, we will illustrate how this connection is clearly presented through examples.
This lecture will include several new results recently achieved by the author and his collaborators.
This work was partially funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG), funding number SFB/TR9.
Integrable systems play an important role in various fields of mathematics as well as in theoretical physics.
They naturally appear, especially when studying solvable lattice models in statistical mechanics or quantum field theory.
It has been proven that there is a profound relationship between analyticity and special geometric structures, known as algebraic curves.
These curves provide powerful tools for accurately solving certain physical problems through algebraic geometry methods (such as Riemann surfaces and θ functions).

We proposed a network self-organization method based on multi-agent systems (MAS).
