We present new results on the impact of clumping effects in modeling stellar winds on their observed linear and circular polarization characteristics, using Monte Carlo radiation transfer simulations.

We found that for stars with a high mass loss rate (Ṁ > 10^-7 M⊙ yr^-1), the presence of clusters can significantly affect the degree and angle of linear polarization produced by scattering processes in the wind.

We have proposed an open-source framework called Bubblesched, which allows for the construction of portable thread schedulers for Heterogeneous Multi-processors (HMPs).
The main idea is to use bubbles as scheduling units and to schedule them at different levels of the HMP hierarchy using a set of rules.
We have implemented two schedulers: one based on work stealing and the other based on load balancing.
These two schedulers can run efficiently on Bubblesched without any modifications.
Our experimental results show that when running parallel applications for fine-grained tasks, the performance of these two schedulers exceeds that of state-of-the-art solutions by up to 3 times.
In addition, we demonstrate how our scheduler can be used to implement efficient task parallel algorithms, such as graph coloring or matrix multiplication.

We propose an accurate and efficient fundamental measure theory (FMT) method to describe fluids composed of rigidly arranged hard hexagons, which are relevant as model systems for liquid crystals or colloidal suspensions with anisotropic interactions.

We propose an evolutionary model to describe the evolution of regulatory mechanisms that control the cell division rate in growing populations.

The model is based on the following assumption: cells can evolve to optimize their fitness by adjusting their growth rates according to environmental conditions (such as nutrient availability or population density).
We demonstrate how this simple principle leads to the emergence of complex regulatory networks, which have multiple feedback loops and time delays.
Our results show that these networks are highly robust to mutations but very sensitive to changes in external conditions.
This may explain why many organisms have evolved similar regulatory circuits despite differences in their genetic backgrounds.

The purpose of this article is to outline some recent research findings on quantum field theory (QFT) in curved space with non-commutative coordinates.

The main motivation for studying quantum field theory in such spaces comes from string theory, which is expressed as open strings attached to D-branes, with their positions describable by non-commutative matrices.

We will prove that a covariant derivative operator can be defined, acting on fields living on the Groenewold-Moyal plane.

We study the Leonard triple system, which is a finite set of points in a projective space defined over a field, such that any three distinct points determine a line.
We demonstrated how to construct all Leonard triples with parameters \( n = 3m + 1 \) or \( n = 3m + 2 \), where \( m \) is a positive integer.

1 Introduction

Lattice Quantum Chromodynamics (LQCD), as one of the most promising candidate theories for describing the strong interactions between quarks and gluons, has been widely used to study the properties of hadrons, such as mass and decay constants [1].

However, it faces the so-called "sign problem": the sign of the fermionic determinant \( \text{det} D_m = \exp[-\text{tr}\{D_m\}\ln m] \) can vary depending on the gauge configuration [2], where \( D_m \) denotes the Wilson-Dirac operator [3].
Therefore, the Monte Carlo method cannot be directly used to compute physical quantities through lattice quantum chromodynamics (LQCD) because it requires a positive definite weighting function.
To overcome this difficulty, several methods have been developed to date [5] - [8].

The main goal of this work is to study the impact of different types of initial conditions on the evolution of density perturbations in an expanding universe with a positive cosmological constant (dark energy).

We used two numerical methods to solve the Einstein equations coupled to matter fields: one is the standard method based on expanding the metric tensor into spherical harmonics; the other is a new method we developed, which utilizes expanding the metric in Chebyshev polynomials.

In these two cases, we considered three types of initial conditions: Gaussian random fields generated using the Zel'dovich approximation, Gaussian random fields generated using the Fast Fourier Transform algorithm, and white noise.
Our results indicate that these models provide similar predictions when evolved to z = 0.5.
However, there are some differences between them in the early stages.

These differences can be explained as follows: The fluctuations predicted by the Zel'dovich model are larger than those predicted by other models because it does not take into account the pressure term in the fluid equations; the white noise model yields smaller fluctuations due to its statistical characteristics; finally, the Gaussian random field obtained through the fast Fourier transform algorithm predicts intermediate values.
This result suggests that the choice of initial conditions may significantly influence the final values of the power spectrum of the original density fluctuations predicted by inflationary theory.

We propose a new method for determining the mass loss rate of asymptotic giant branch stars (AGB) using centimeter-band radio observations, and we compare these results with those obtained from measurements of infrared dust emission.
We used archived VLA data from three nearby carbon-rich AGB stars, namely IK Tau, IRC+10216, and AFGL 3068, which are known for their high mass loss rates.

The observed flux density was compared with the predicted results obtained using a spherically symmetric radiative transfer model, which includes contributions from free-free and thermal dust radiation emission.
For each star, when assuming an appropriate mass loss rate, our model predicts a good consistency with the observed flux density values.
Our results show that the mass loss rate derived from continuous radio observations can serve as a reliable estimate of the total mass loss during the late stages of stellar evolution.
These results also demonstrate how radio observations provide important constraints for theoretical envelope models of circumstellar environments around mature stars.
We report the observation of electron spin transport over macroscopic distances (several millimeters) in suspended monolayer graphene devices at room temperature.

The experiment employs non-local spin valve measurements, using ferromagnetic contacts made from cobalt/nickel multilayer films deposited by sputtering. The contact materials are attached to peeled graphite sheets, which are then annealed to form cobalt silicide contacts.

We observed that the resistance-area product RA is highly dependent on the contact geometry; for example, we found that when the length of one of the contacts exceeds 1 micron, RA significantly decreases.
This behavior can be explained by considering the disorder scattering effects near the interface of metal and carbon atoms.
In addition, we indicate that the magnitude of the spin signal is very sensitive to the relative orientation of the magnetization directions of the two ferromagnets.

These results indicate that the observed spin signals are primarily due to spin injection into the graphene layer, rather than being dominated by neighboring effects or other mechanisms related to the magnetic contacts themselves.

We present new near-infrared (NIR) polarized observations of the GG Tau system, revealing a complex disk structure around the star that contains several bright regions with different polarization characteristics.
The most significant feature in our dataset is an arc-like structure located approximately 0.5 arcseconds southeast of the central binary star.
The region exhibits strong polarized radiation, with an intensity of up to 10% of the total intensity, and it has previously been identified as a reflection nebula by Weintraub et al. (1993).

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have become promising materials for field emission devices due to their unique physical and chemical properties, such as high aspect ratio, low work function, and excellent mechanical strength.
In this study, we propose an integrated multiphysics model that can be used to simulate the system response of carbon nanotube (CNT)-based field emission diodes (FEDs).
The proposed model consists of three sub-models: 1) electron transport in CNT; 2) electric potential distribution; 3) current density distribution.
We developed these models using the COMSOL Multiphysics software package with built-in physics modules.

In order to verify our simulation results, we grew vertically aligned carbon nanotubes on a silicon substrate using plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition. Subsequently, we sputtered a gold film on top of them, thereby creating a carbon nanotube field-effect device.
Our experimental data show good consistency with the simulation results obtained from the proposed model.
